ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 8691
   AN ORDINANCE TO APPROVE AND ADOPT A HAMMOND CITY CODE
   WHEREAS, the City Clerk of the City of Hammond has caused to be prepared by
American Legal Publishing Co., Cincinnati, Ohio (“American Legal”), a single
volume codification of the ordinances of the City of Hammond (“City”); and
   WHEREAS, American Legal has prepared such a volume and presented it to the
City of Hammond for adoption as a new codification of the City's ordinances;
and
   WHEREAS, it is the intent of the Common Council of the City to adopt such
volume as a codification of the city's ordinances;
   NOW, THEREFORE BE IT ORDAINED BY THE COMMON COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF HAMMOND
as follows:
   1.)   The looseleaf, three ring volume printed and published in 2005 by
American Legal be and is hereby adopted and approved by reference, as if here
set out in its entirety, as the codified version of the ordinances of the City.
   2.)   This volume shall be known as the “Hammond City Code” or “The Code of
Ordinance of the City of Hammond, Indiana.”
   3.)   Until existing supplies of pre-printed notices of ordinance violations
are exhausted, but in no event later than one year after the effective date of
this ordinance, any police officer or other employee or official of the City,
may continue to use such existing supplies of pre-printed notices of ordinance
violations, not withstanding that numbered references may be to the prior
version of the Hammond City Code and not the version adopted by this ordinance.
Any such references to the prior version of the Hammond City Code shall be
construed as referring correctly to the newly adopted Hammond City Code.
   4.)   If any part, paragraph, sentence or provision of this ordinance shall
be held invalid, the remainder shall not be affected.
   5.)   This ordinance shall be effective upon final passage by the Common
Council, approval of the Mayor, or override of any Mayoral veto, and its
publication (if required) as provided by law.
   PASSED by the Common Council of the City of Hammond this 12th day of
September 2005
                                                                                
                              Daniel C. Repay /s/
                              Daniel C. Repay, President
                              Hammond Common Council
ATTEST:
                                                  
Robert J. Golec /s/

City for his approval or veto on the 13th day of September, 2005.
                                                                                
                              Robert J. Golec /s/
                              Robert J. Golec, City Clerk
   The foregoing Ordinance Number 8691, consisting of two pages, including this
page is hereby approved by me, the Mayor, this 16th day of September, 2005.
                                                                             
                           Thomas M. McDermott, Jr. /s/

ORDINANCE NO. 8917
AN ORDINANCE ENACTING AND ADOPTING A SUPPLEMENT TO THE CODE OF ORDINANCES FOR
THE CITY OF HAMMOND, INDIANA AND DECLARING AN EMERGENCY
   WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio, has
completed the supplements to the Code of Ordinances of the City of Hammond,
Indiana; and
   WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation has recommended the revision
or addition of certain sections of the Code of Ordinances which are based on or
make reference to sections of the Indiana Code; and
   WHEREAS, it is the intent of the Legislative Authority to accept these
updated sections in accordance with the changes of the law of the State of
Indiana; and
   WHEREAS, it is necessary to provide for the usual daily operation of the
municipality and for the immediate preservation of public peace, health, safety
and general welfare of the municipality that this ordinance take effect at an
early date;
   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE LEGISLATIVE AUTHORITY OF THE CITY OF
HAMMOND, INDIANA AS FOLLOWS:
   1.)   That the 2007 S-4, 2007 S-3, 2006 S-2 and 2005 S-1, supplements to the
Code of Ordinances of the City of Hammond, Indiana as submitted by American
Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio be and the same is hereby
adopted by reference as if set out in its entirety.
   2.)   Such supplement shall be deemed published as of the day of its
adoption and approval by the Legislative Authority and the Clerk of the City of
Hammond, Indiana is hereby authorized and ordered to insert such supplement
into the copy of the Code of Ordinances kept on file in the Office of the
Clerk.
   3.)   This ordinance is declared to be an emergency measure necessary for
the immediate preservation of the peace, health, safety and general welfare of
the people of this municipality, and shall take effect at the earliest date
provided by law.
   PASSED AND ADOPTED by the Legislative Authority of the City of Hammond,
Indiana on this 25th day of February, 2008.
   Daniel C. Repay /s/
   Daniel C. Repay, President
   Hammond Common Council
ATTEST:
Robert J. Golec /s/
Robert J. Golec, City Clerk
   PRESENTED by me, the undersigned City Clerk of the City of Hammond to the
Mayor of said City for his approval on the 26th day of February, 2008.
   Robert J. Golec /s/
   Robert J. Golec, City Clerk
   The foregoing Ordinance Number 8917, consisting of two (2) typewritten
pages, including this page was approved by the Mayor, the 26th day of February,
2008.

   WHEREAS, it is necessary to provide for the usual daily operation of the
municipality and for the immediate preservation of public peace, health, safety

early date;
   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE LEGISLATIVE AUTHORITY OF THE CITY OF
HAMMOND, INDIANA AS FOLLOWS:

Ordinances of the City of Hammond, Indiana as submitted by American Legal
Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio be and the same is hereby adopted by

adoption and approval by the Legislative Authority and the Clerk of the City of

Clerk.

for the immediate preservation of the peace, health, safety and general welfare
of the people of this municipality, and shall take effect at the earliest date
provided by law.

ORDINANCE NO. 9067
   AN ORDINANCE ENACTING AND ADOPTING A SUPPLEMENT TO THE CODE OF ORDINANCES
FOR THE CITY OF HAMMOND, INDIANA
   WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio, has
completed the supplements to the Code of Ordinances of the City of Hammond,
Indiana; and
   WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation has recommended the revision
or addition of certain sections of the Code of Ordinances which are based on or
make reference to sections of the Indiana code; and
   WHEREAS, it is the intent of the Legislative Authority to accept these
updated sections in accordance with the changes of the law of the State of
Indiana; and
   WHEREAS, it is necessary to provide for the usual daily operation of the
municipality and for the immediate preservation of public peace, health, safety
and general welfare of the municipality that this ordinance take effect at an
early date;
   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE LEGISLATIVE AUTHORITY OF THE CITY OF
HAMMOND, INDIANA:
Section 1.   That the 2010 S-8 supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City
of Hammond, Indiana as submitted by American Legal Publishing Corporation of
Cincinnati, Ohio be and the same is hereby adopted by reference as if set out
in its entirety.
Section 2.   Such supplement shall be deemed published as of the day of its
adoption and approval by the Legislative Authority and the Clerk of the City of
Hammond, Indiana is hereby authorized and ordered to insert such supplement
into the copy of the Code of Ordinances kept on file in the Office of the
Clerk.
Section 3.   This ordinance is for the immediate preservation of the peace,
health, safety and general welfare of the people of this municipality, and
shall take effect at the earliest date provided by law.
   PASSED AND ADOPTED by the Legislative Authority of the City of Hammond,
Indiana on this 14th day of June, 2010.

§ 10.01 TITLE OF CODE.
   (A)   The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall
constitute and be designated as “The Code of Ordinances of the City of Hammond,
Indiana,” and may be so cited.
   (B)   This code may also be cited as the “Hammond City Code.”
(Prior Code, § 10.01)
§ 10.02 INTERPRETATION.
   (A)   Unless otherwise provided herein, or by law or implication required,
the same rules of construction, definition and application shall govern the
interpretation of this code as those governing the interpretation of the
Indiana Code.
   (B)   (1)   Where a section of this code is followed by a reference to the
Indiana Code, the reference indicates that the section is analogous or similar
to the cited sections in the Indiana Code.
      (2)   Footnotes, cross-references and other comments are by way of
explanation only and should not be deemed a part of the text of any section.
   (C)   All provisions of this code are limited in application to the
territorial boundaries of the municipal corporation although the provisions may
not be so limited specifically.
   (D)   Code, title, chapter and section headings do not constitute any part
of the law as contained in the code.
   (E)   (1)   Each of the sections of this code at the end of which there
appears, in parentheses, an historical citation indicating the ordinance
existing at the time of the adoption of this code from which the section
derives, is hereby determined and declared to be a restatement and reenactment
of that section or ordinance and amendment thereto, heretofore properly
adopted, and each section shall be deemed reordained by the passage and
adoption of this code.
      (2)   An historical citation at the end of a section of this code shall
constitute the determination and declaration of restatement and reenactment of
that section required by law.
(Prior Code, § 10.02)
§ 10.03 APPLICATION TO FUTURE ORDINANCES.
   All provisions of Title I not incompatible with future legislation, shall
apply to ordinances hereafter adopted amending or supplementing this code
unless otherwise specifically provided.
(Prior Code, § 10.03)
§ 10.04 CAPTIONS.
   The headings of the several sections of this code are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections, and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of these sections, nor as any part of the section, nor,
unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of the sections,
including the headings, are amended or reenacted.
(Prior Code, § 10.04)
§ 10.05 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this code, the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BOARD. The Board of Public Works and Safety.
   CITY, MUNICIPAL CORPORATION or MUNICI- PALITY. The City of Hammond, Indiana.
   THIS CODE or THIS CODE OF ORDINANCES. The municipal code as modified by
amendment, revision and adoption of new titles, chapters or sections.
   COUNCIL. The Common Council of the City of Hammond.
   COUNTY. Lake County, Indiana.
   I.C. Indiana Code.
   MAY. The act referred to is permissive.
   MONTH. A calendar month.
   OATH. An affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be
substituted for an OATH and, in these cases, the words SWEAR and SWORN shall be
equivalent to the words AFFIRM and AFFIRMED.
   OCCUPANT. See TENANT.
   OWNER. Applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner,
tenant in common, tenant in partnership or joint tenant of the whole or a part
of the building or land, either alone or with others.
   PERSON. Extends to and includes person, persons, firm, corporation,
copartnership, trustee, lessee or receiver. Whenever used in any clause
prescribing and imposing a penalty, the terms PERSON or WHOEVER, as applied to
any unincorporated entity, shall mean the partners or members thereof, and as
applied to corporations, the officers thereof.
   PERSONAL PROPERTY. Every species of property, except real property.
   PRECEDING or FOLLOWING. Next before and next after, respectively.
   PROPERTY. Real and personal property.
   PUBLIC PLACE. Any street or highway, sidewalk, park, cemetery, school yard
or open space adjacent thereto and any lake or stream.
   REAL PROPERTY. Lands, tenements, hereditaments and all chattels real.
   SHALL. The act referred to is mandatory.
   SIDEWALK. The portion of a street between the curb lines of the lateral
lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines intended for the use of
pedestrians, excluding parkways.
   SIGNATURE or SUBSCRIPTION. Includes a mark when the person cannot write.
   STATE. State of Indiana.
   STATE LAW REFERENCES. Whenever reference is made to Burns’ Stat., it shall
be construed to refer to Burns’ Indiana Statutes, or to any subsequent
amendment.
   STREET. Except as provided in the traffic code, the entire width between
property lines of every way or place of whatever nature when any part thereof
is open to the use of the public, as a matter of right.
   SUBCHAPTER. A division of a chapter, designated in this code by an
underlined heading in the chapter analysis and capitalized heading in the body
of the chapter, setting apart a group of sections related by the subject matter
of the heading. Not all chapters have SUBCHAPTERS.
   SUBSCRIPTION. See SIGNATURE.
   TENANT or OCCUPANT. Applied to a building or land, shall include any person
holding a written or oral lease of, or who occupies the whole or a part of the
building or land, either alone or with others.
   WRITTEN. Any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by
printing or otherwise.
   YEAR. A calendar year, unless otherwise expressed; equivalent to the words
YEAR OF OUR LORD.
(Prior Code, § 10.05)
§ 10.06 RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   The construction of all ordinances of the city shall be by the following
rules, unless the construction is plainly repugnant to the intent of the
legislative body or of the context of the ordinance.
   (A)   AND or OR.  Either conjunction shall include the other as if written
“and/or,” if the sense requires it.
   (B)   Acts by assistants. When a statute requires an act to be done which,
by law, an agent or deputy as well may do as the principal, the requisition
shall be satisfied by the performance of the act by an authorized agent or
deputy.
   (C)   Gender; singular and plural; tenses. Words denoting the masculine
gender shall be deemed to include the feminine and neuter genders; words in the
singular shall include the plural, and words in the plural shall include the
singular; the use of a verb in the present tense shall include the future, if
applicable.
   (D)   General term. A general term following specific enumeration of terms
is not to be limited to the class enumerated unless expressly so limited.
   (E)   Joint authority. Words importing joint authority to 3 or more persons
shall be construed as authority to a majority of these persons, unless
otherwise declared in the law giving the authority.
   (F)   Senses. Words and phrases shall be taken in their plain, ordinary and
usual sense. However, technical words and phrases having a peculiar and
appropriate meaning in law shall be understood according to their technical
import.
(Prior Code, § 10.06)
§ 10.07 SEVERABILITY.
   If any part or parts, section or division, sentence, clause or phrase of
this code, as now or later amended, for any reason declared unconstitutional or
invalid, the decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions
of this code.
(Prior Code, § 10.07)
§ 10.08 REFERENCE TO OTHER SECTIONS.
   Whenever, in 1 section, reference is made to another section hereof, the
reference shall extend and apply to the section referred to as subsequently
amended, revised, recodified or renumbered unless the subject matter is changed
or materially altered by the amendment or revision.
(Prior Code, § 10.08)
§ 10.09 REFERENCE TO OFFICES.
   Reference to a public office or officer shall be deemed to apply to any
office, officer or employee of the municipality exercising the powers, duties
or functions contemplated in the provision, irrespective of any transfer of
functions or change in the official title of the functionary.
(Prior Code, § 10.09)
§ 10.10 ERRORS AND OMISSIONS.
   (A)   If a manifest error is discovered consisting of the misspelling of any
words; the omission of any word or words necessary to express the intention of
the provisions affected; the use of a word or words to which no meaning can be
attached; or the use of a word or words when another word or words was clearly
intended to express the intent, the spelling shall be corrected and the word or
words supplied, omitted or substituted as will conform with the manifest
intention, and the provisions shall have the same effect as though the correct
words were contained in the text as originally published.
   (B)   No alteration shall be made or permitted if any question exists
regarding the nature or extent of the error.
(Prior Code, § 10.10)
§ 10.11 OFFICIAL TIME.
   The official time, as established by applicable state and federal law, shall
be the official time within the city for the transaction of all city business.
(Prior Code, § 10.11)
§ 10.12 COMPUTATION OF TIME.
   (A)   In computing any period of time prescribed or allowed by these rules,
by order of the court or by any applicable statute, the day of the act, event
or default from which the designated period of time begins to run shall not be
included. The last day of the period so computed is to be included unless it
is:
      (1)   A Saturday;
      (2)   A Sunday;
      (3)   A legal holiday as defined by state statute; or
      (4)   A day the office in which the act is to be done is closed during
regular business hours.
   (B)   (1)   In any event, the period runs until the end of the next day that
is not a Saturday, a Sunday, a legal holiday or a day on which the office is
closed.
      (2)   When the period of time allowed is less than 7 days, intermediate
Saturdays, Sundays, legal holidays and days on which the office is closed shall
be excluded from the computation.
(Indiana Rules of Trial Procedure, Rule 6(A))
(Prior Code, § 10.12)
§ 10.13 ORDINANCES REPEALED.
   (A)   This code, from and after its effective date, shall contain all of the
provisions of a general nature pertaining to the subjects herein enumerated and
embraced.
   (B)   All prior ordinances pertaining to the subjects treated by this code
shall be deemed repealed from and after the effective date of this code.
(Prior Code, § 10.13)
§ 10.14 ORDINANCES UNAFFECTED.
   All ordinances of a temporary or special nature and all other ordinances
pertaining to subjects not embraced in this code shall remain in full force and
effect unless herein repealed expressly or by necessary implication.
(Prior Code, § 10.14)
§ 10.15 CITY SEAL.
   (A)   The device set out below is hereby designated as the official seal of
the city.
   (B)   This seal shall be affixed to all instruments or writings of the city
needing authentication, and the Clerk of the Common Council is ordered to have
a die cast for making an impression of the seal.
(Prior Code, § 10.15)

IMAGES/0-0-0-3503.gif]
 
§ 10.16 OFFENSES PUNISHABLE UNDER SEPARATE PROVISIONS.
   In all cases where the same offenses may be punishable, or may be created by
different clauses or sections of the ordinances of the city, the City Attorney
may elect under which to proceed, but not more than 1 recovery shall be had
against the same person for the same offense.
(Prior Code, § 10.16)
§ 10.17 COMMEMORATIVE DAYS.
   The first Monday in March shall be set apart for the recognition of Casimir
Pulaski’s birthday and is hereby designated as “Casimir Pulaski Day.” On this
commemorative day, suitable exercises may be held in the public schools of the
city and by citizens generally throughout the city as an appropriate and
patriotic observance of Casimir Pulaski’s great contributions to the cause of
the American Revolution.
(Prior Code, § 10.17)
§ 10.98 ORDINANCE VIOLATIONS BUREAU; ADMISSION OF VIOLATION.
   (A)   There shall be created an Ordinance Violations Bureau for the city,
and the City Clerk shall serve as the Violations Clerk of the Bureau.
   (B)   The City Clerk is appointed the Violations Clerk and shall accept
written appearances, waivers of trial, admissions of violations and payment of
civil penalties of not more than the statutory limit set forth in I.C. 33-36-2-
3(4) in ordinance violations cases.
   (C)   The ordinances subject to administration by the Ordinance Violations
Bureau shall be designated by proper schedule and may be otherwise identified
throughout the Code of Ordinances. The schedule may be amended from time to
time by action of the City Council to add or delete qualified ordinances or to
increase or decrease any civil penalty.
   (D)   The scheduled ordinance violations are determined to be payable
offenses which are subject to admission before the Violations Clerk, and the
violator may elect to pay a civil penalty directly to the Violations Clerk
without the necessity of appearing in court.
   (E)   Civil penalties shall be paid to, receipted by, and accounted for by
the Clerk under procedures provided for by the State Board of Accounts.
Payments of civil penalties may be made in person or by mail.
   (F)   Certain ordinance violations may, at the discretion of the city’s Law
Department, be resolved by proof of compliance with the cited ordinance rather
than the assessment of a civil penalty. Those ordinances shall be designated by
proper schedule and may be otherwise identified throughout the Code of
Ordinances. Upon receipt of notification of compliance by the Law Department or
any person authorized by the Law Department to determine compliance, the
Violations Clerk shall consider such violations resolved and dismiss same.
   (G)   A person charged with a violation of a provision of the Code of
Ordinances is entitled to a trial before a court as provided by law, unless the
person waives the right to trial and enters an admission of the violation with
the Violations Clerk.
   (H)   Upon an admission of an ordinance violation, the Violations Clerk
shall assess and collect from the violator the amount prescribed by the
Schedule of Civil Penalties established under this section. Payment of the
civil penalty shall be made within 30 days from the date of the citation unless
an extension is allowed by the Law Department or its designee. However, payment
of the civil penalty for scheduled parking violations under Chapter 72 and
Chapter 73 shall be made within 60 days from the date of the citation unless an
extension is allowed by the Law Department or its designee.
   (I)   Any person paying a civil penalty at the Ordinance Violations Bureau
shall execute a waiver of right to trial and admission of the violation.
   (J)   Except as otherwise provided, an ordinance violation admitted in the
Ordinance Violation Bureau and resolved by payment of a civil penalty or
compliance does not constitute a judgment for the purposes of I.C. 33-37, and
ordinance violation cost fees may not be collected or assessed by the Ordinance
Violations Bureau under I.C. 33-37-4. An ordinance violation that is resolved
within the Ordinance Violations Bureau may not be considered for the purposes
of I.C. 33-37-7-6 when determining the percentage of ordinance violations
prosecuted in certain courts.
   (K)   Any person charged with a violation of a provision of the Code of
Ordinances who desires to exercise the right to trial may appear before the
Violations Clerk and deny the violation or enter a written denial of violation
with the Violations Clerk.
   (L)   The Violations Clerk shall report to the Law Department if a person
(1) denies an ordinance violation; (2) fails to demonstrate compliance; (3)
fails to pay, within the time permitted by ordinance including any extensions,
the civil penalty assessed by the Violations Clerk after having entered an
admission of the violation; or (4) fails to admit or deny the violation within
30 days from the date of the citation or within 60 days from the date of the
citation under Chapter 72 or Chapter 73.
   (M)   Proceedings in a court of proper jurisdiction shall be initiated
against any alleged violator of ordinance who has denied the violation or who
has failed to either demonstrate compliance, pay the applicable civil penalty,
or admit or deny the violation within 30 days after the date of the citation.
   (N)   Notwithstanding the establishment of the Ordinance Violations Bureau
and a Schedule of Civil Penalties, no part of this section shall be construed
to prohibit the city, through its Law Department or other designee, from
seeking the greater penalties provided for by any applicable ordinance when
proceeding in a court of proper jurisdiction.
   (O)   Civil penalties for the scheduled ordinances shall be assessed and
collected by the Violations Clerk and pursuant to division (H) as follows:

§ 10.99 GENERAL PENALTY.
   (A)   Whenever in this code or in any ordinance of the city, or in any rule
or regulation promulgated by an officer or agency thereof, under authority
invested by law or ordinance, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to
be unlawful or an offense or the doing of an act is required, or the failure to
do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided
therefor, the violation of such a provision of this code, ordinance, rule or
regulation shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $2,500. Every day any
violation of this code or any ordinance, rule or regulation shall continue
shall constitute a separate offense.
   (B)   In cases where a previous conviction exists under division (A) of this
section, the violation of this second (or subsequent) provision of code,
ordinance, rule or regulation shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $7,500.
Continuing violations shall constitute a separate offense.
(Prior Code, § 10.99) (Ord. 4832, passed 7-11-1983; Am. Ord. 8783, passed 9-11-
2006)
CHAPTER 11: BOUNDARIES
Section
   
11.01   City boundaries
§ 11.01 CITY BOUNDARIES.
   All of the land lying within the following described boundaries shall be,
and is hereby declared to be within the corporate boundaries of the city, and
the following described boundaries shall be and constitute the corporate
boundaries of the city: Commencing on the state line between the states of
Indiana and Illinois, where the shore line of Lake Michigan intersects the
state line; then south along the state line to a point where the state line
intersects the north bank of the Little Calumet River at low water mark in
Section 12, Township 36 North, Range 10 West of the Second Principal Meridian;
then easterly along the meanderings of the north bank of the Little Calumet
River at low water mark to the east line of Section 15 in Township 36 North,
Range 9 West of the Second Principal Meridian; then north along the east line
of Section 15, Section 10 and Section 3 in Township 36 North, Range 9 West of
the Second Principal Meridian and Section 34 in Township 37 North, Range 9 West
of the Second Principal Meridian, to the south bank of the Grand Calumet River
at low water mark in Section 34; then westerly along the south bank of the
Grand Calumet River at low water mark in Section 34 and Section 33, Township 37
North, Range 9 West of the Second Principal Meridian to the west line of the
east half of Section 33; then south along the west line of the east half of
Section 33 to the north line of Section 4, Township 36 North, Range 9 West of
the Second Principal Meridian; then west along the north line of Section 4 and
Section 5 Township 36 North, Range 9 West of the Second Principal Meridian to
the northwest corner of Section 5; then north along the east line of Section
31, Section 30, Section 19 and Section 18, Township 37 North, Range 9 West of
the Second Principal Meridian to the northeast corner of the southeast quarter
of the northeast quarter of Section 18, Township 37 North, Range 9 West of the
Second Principal Meridian; then 330 feet; then north 660 feet; then east 330
feet to the east line of the northeast quarter of Section 18, Township 37
North, Range 9 West of the Second Principal Meridian; then continuing along the
east lines of Section 18 and Section 7 in Township 37 North, Range 9 West of
the Second Principal Meridian to a point 521 feet south of the northeast corner
of the southeast quarter of Section 7, which point is the north right-of-way
line of the Indiana Harbor Belt R.R., formerly known as the Hammond and Blue
Island Railroad; then westerly on the north right-of-way line of the railroad
to the center line of Indianapolis Boulevard; then northwesterly along the
center line of Indianapolis Boulevard 551.5 feet to where the centerline
intersects the north line of the southeast quarter of Section 7, and which
point is located 1,289.75 feet west of the northwest corner of the southeast
quarter of Section 7; then along the north line of the southeast quarter of
Section 7 to the northwest corner of the southeast quarter of Section 7; then
north along the east line of the west fractional one-half (or north and south
center line) of Sections 7 and 6, Township 37 North, Range 9 West of the Second
Principal Meridian to the point where the line intersects the shoreline of Lake
Michigan; then northwesterly along the meanderings of the shoreline of Lake
Michigan through Section 6, Township 37 North, Range 9 West of the Second
Principal Meridian, Section l, Township 37 North, Range 10 West of the Second
Principal Meridian and Section 36, Township 38 North, Range 10 West of the
Second Principal Meridian to the intersection of the shoreline of Lake Michigan
with the state line between the states of Indiana and Illinois to the place of
beginning.
(Prior Code, § 11.01)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 30.01 COUNCILMANIC DISTRICTS.
   The city is hereby divided into 6 districts as follows:
   (A)   The first district shall be composed of the following precincts, as
now established: H1-01; H1-03; H1-05; H1-07; H1-08; H1-10; H1-12; H1-16.
   (B)   The second district shall be composed of the following precincts, as
now established: H2-03; H2-05; H2-06; H2-11; H2-12; H2-14.
   (C)   The third district shall be composed of the following precincts, as
now established: H3-03; H3-04; H3-05; H3-07; H3-09; H3-11; H3-16.
   (D)   The fourth district shall be composed of the following precincts, as
now established: H4-05; H4-06; H4-07; H4-09; H4-11; H4-12; H4-14; H4-18.
   (E)   The fifth district shall be composed of the following precincts, as
now established: H5-04; H5-08; H5-12; H5-13; H5-14; H5-15; H5-17.
   (F)   The sixth district shall be composed of the following precincts, as
now established: H6-04; H6-05; H6-07; H6-08; H6-09; H6-10; H6-12; H6-13; H6-15.
(Prior Code, § 30.01) (Ord. 7554, passed 12-14-1992; Am. Ord. 8452, passed 10-
28-2002; Am. Ord. 9168, passed 8-13-2012; Am. Ord. 9569, passed 10-11-2022)
Statutory reference:
   Council election districts in second-class cities, see I.C. 36-4-6-3
§ 30.02 ELECTION OF PRESIDENT, VICE-PRESIDENT; TERM.
   (A)   The Mayor may act as temporary chairperson at the first meeting of the
Common Council after the inaugural of elected officials of the city. In the
absence of the Mayor, the Council shall elect a temporary chairperson for this
meeting from their ranks by majority vote of the members present.
   (B)   The meeting shall be conducted in accordance with state law relative
to election of officers of the Common Council.
   (C)   (1)   A President and a Vice-President shall serve for a period of 1
year.
      (2)   The election shall be conducted at each annual date thereafter
except as otherwise specified in this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 30.02) (Ord. 3408, passed 1-27-1964; Am. Ord. 7023, passed 4-11-
1988)
§ 30.03 STANDING COMMITTEES.
   (A)   The President, with the approval of the majority of the Common
Council, shall appoint all standing and special committees. The standing
committees shall consist of the following: City Plan, Economic Development and
Finance.
   (B)   Whenever a matter pertaining to an individual district is referred to
any standing or special committee, the Council member from the Councilmanic
district affected, if not a member of that standing or special committee, shall
become a member of that standing or special committee for the purposes of
considering the matter pending before the committee concerning his or her
district.
(Prior Code, § 30.03) (Ord. 3268, passed 1-4-1960; Am. Ord. 3285, passed 5-9-
1960; Am. Ord. 3313, passed 1-9-1961; Am. Ord. 3408, passed 1-27-1964; Am. Ord.
7023, passed 4-11-1988; Am. Ord. 7471, passed 3-23-1992)
§ 30.04 COPIES OF MINUTES, AGENDAS AND OTHER WRITINGS TO BE PROVIDED TO
COUNCIL.
   Each and every public agency of the city as that term is defined in I.C. 5-
14-1.5-2, including but not limited to the Board of Public Works and Safety,
the Equal Employment Opportunity Committee, the Park Board, the Recreation
Commission, the Water Board, the Housing Authority, the Hammond Sanitary
District, the Human Relations Commission, the Redevelopment Commission, the
Plan Commission, the Board of Zoning Appeals and the Economic Development
Commission shall provide the Common Council in care of the City Clerk with 11
copies of all minutes, agendas and other memoranda or writing required by the
Indiana Open Door Law, I.C. 5-14-1.5, as they are prepared.
(Prior Code, § 30.04) (Ord. 4890, passed 6-25-1984)
§ 30.05 CITY RADIO PROVIDED TO EACH COUNCILPERSON.
   (A)   Each Councilperson who requests 1 shall be given a city radio with all
channels that can both transmit and receive.
   (B)   These radios shall be tied into the city radio system.
   (C)   The Chief of Police shall be responsible for providing the requested
working equipment.
(Prior Code, § 30.05) (Ord. 8256, passed 4-10-2000)
§ 30.06 POLICE OFFICER TO BE PRESENT AT COUNCIL MEETINGS.
   (A)   The City Police Department shall provide a minimum of 1 uniformed on-
duty police officer to be present at all meetings of the Hammond Common
Council.
   (B)   That these meetings include the regularly scheduled monthly meetings,
including the period before the meeting during which the caucus takes place.
   (C)   The assigned officer shall remain at the meeting place until the
conclusion of the meeting, which shall include until all the Council members
leave.
(Prior Code, § 30.06) (Ord. 8493, passed 6-9-2003)
Cross-reference:
   Police Department, see
Ch. 32
§ 30.07 RESTRICTIONS OF CELLULAR PHONES DURING COUNCIL MEETINGS.
   Any person who is present in the Common Council Chambers while the Common
Council is conducting a meeting must have any and all cellular phones, pagers,
or electronic devices on vibrate or silent mode. Any person wishing to receive
or make a phone call shall leave the Council Chambers in order to do so.
(Prior Code, § 30.07) (Ord. 8548, passed 3-8-2004; Am. Ord. 9125, passed 12-19-
2011)
§ 30.08 PAYMENT FOR COUNCIL CELL PHONES PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No city funds of any kind may be used to pay for cellular phones used
by any member of the Common Council of the city.
   (B)   It shall be the responsibility of every member of the Common Council
who has a cellular phone paid for by the city to turn in the cellular phone and
to cooperate in every way in terminating the cellular phone contract.
(Ord. 8665, passed 3-14-2005)
§ 30.09 PROCEDURE FOR RENAMING STREETS AND NEIGHBORHOODS.
   (A)   The Common Council shall have the authority to rename any street,
neighborhood or other part of the city by ordinance. No federal, county.
township, state and private road or property located in the city shall be
renamed without the consent of the owner. Prior to the adoption of any such
ordinance, the Common Council shall conduct a public hearing and permit all
persons affected to state their positions orally or in writing. Honorary names
for streets shall not affect legal addresses. Before renaming any street, the
Common Council shall give due consideration to any financial burden on any
homeowner or business or any confusion created by such renaming.
   (B)   It shall be the policy of Common Council that, except for police,
fire, military persons and elected officials not to consider renaming any
street, neighborhood or area for any deceased individual unless the honored
individual has been deceased four or more years.
(Ord. 8830, passed 2-12-07)
RULES OF PROCEDURE
§ 30.20 ROBERT’S RULES OF ORDER.
   Robert’s Rules of Order Newly Revised, 11th Edition, shall govern the
conduct of the business of the Common Council and its members, in all cases
where they are applicable and not inconsistent with the other provisions of
this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 30.10) (Am. Ord. 7450, passed 1-13-1992; Am. Ord. 9131, passed
1-23-2012)
§ 30.21 TIME OF REGULAR MEETINGS; ADJOURNMENT.
   Regular meetings of the Common Council shall be held on the second and
fourth Monday of each month during the year. These regular meetings may be
adjourned at the pleasure of the Common Council and the adjourned meetings
shall have the force and effect of regular meetings. The meetings of the Common
Council shall begin at 6:00 p.m.
(Prior Code, § 30.11) (Ord. 5014, passed 3-24-1986; Am. Ord. 7007, passed 12-
14-1987; Am. Ord. 9132, passed 1-23-2012)
§ 30.22 SPECIAL AND EMERGENCY MEETINGS.
   (A)   Special meetings. The President of the Common Council shall call
special meetings of the Council upon the written request of any 5 members, or
whenever, in his or her opinion, the public business may require it. Special
meetings are to be called by summons or notice in writing, signed by the
President of the Common Council and served by reading or by copy on all the
members of the Council.
   (B)   Emergency meetings. The President of the Common Council or the Mayor
may call an emergency meeting of the Council when either or each of them deems
an emergency exists by reason of an act of providence, war, flood, riot,
insurrection, fire or any other emergency that is not an ordinary accepted
regular practice or course of city business as the rules have already
specified.
(Prior Code, § 30.12) (Ord. 3408, passed 1-27-1964)
§ 30.23 ROLL CALL.
   The roll call of members of the Common Council shall at all times and for
all purposes be called in the following order: the Council members elected by
districts shall be called in numerical order of their districts and shall be
called after the at-large Council members, and the at-large Council members
shall be called in the alphabetical order of their names except that the
presiding officer of the Council shall be called last.
(Prior Code, § 30.13) (Ord. 3408, passed 1-27-1964; Am. Ord. 7352, passed 2-25-
1991)
§ 30.24 QUORUM.
   A majority of all the elected members shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of any and all business except as otherwise provided in this
chapter or state law.
(Prior Code, § 30.14) (Ord. 3408, passed 1-27-1964)
§ 30.25 ORDER OF BUSINESS; SUSPENSION OF ORDER.
   (A)   The following order of business shall be observed by the Common
Council at its meeting.
      (1)   Invocation;
      (2)   Calling of the roll and noting the members present and absent;
      (3)   Reading and correcting the journal of the preceding regular or
special meeting;
      (4)   Public hearing, if any;
      (5)   Reports from city officers and other communications;
      (6)   Reports from all regular committees in alphabetical order;
      (7)   Reports from special committees;
      (8)   Ordinances on third reading;
      (9)   Ordinances on second readings;
      (10)   Introduction of ordinances;
      (11)   Introduction and passage of resolutions;
      (12)   Unfinished business;
      (13)   New business; and
      (14)   Public expression.
(Ord. 4508, passed 3-27-1979; Am. Ord. 7023, passed 4-11-1988)
   (B)   (1)   The order of business prescribed in division (A) above may be
suspended at any time by the majority consent of the members present.
      (2)   In case the business of any 1 meeting shall not have been completed
according to the list above, at the next subsequent meeting the order of
business shall be resumed where it left off.
      (3)   However, at the beginning of each meeting the roll call shall be
taken and the journal read unless upon motion the reading shall be dispensed
with.
(Ord. 3408, passed 1-27-1964)
(Prior Code, § 30.15)
§ 30.26 TEMPORARY CHAIRPERSON.
   In the absence of the President and Vice-President when a quorum is present,
the Common Council may elect from their own ranks a temporary chairman for such
meeting by a majority vote of those present.
(Prior Code, § 30.16) (Ord. 3408, passed 1-27-1964)
§ 30.27 MAYOR MAY SPEAK, DEBATE.
   (A)   The Mayor shall have the right to speak on any question and take part
in any debate.
   (B)   While participating in debate, he or she shall be subject to all the
rules governing the Common Council.
(Prior Code, § 30.17)
§ 30.28 AUTHORITY TO ADDRESS COUNCIL.
   (A)   No one not a member of the Common Council, shall be permitted to
address the Common Council except by petition, unless by the consent of 2/3 of
the Council present. Any city officer may, when called upon, make a verbal
report, provided the report be confined to his or her department.
   (B)   (1)   Any member of the public may address the Council under the
agenda item of public expression, but only if the member of the public first
sign in with the City Clerk prior to the commencement of the public expression
period of the Common Council meeting, giving his or her name, address,
telephone number and the subject on which he or she wishes to speak.
      (2)   Members of the public speaking during the public expression period
shall be limited to 3 minutes unless the Council President or a majority of the
members of the Common Council permit the person to speak longer.
(Prior Code, § 30.18) (Ord. 7023, passed 4-11-1988)
§ 30.29 DISPLAY OF SIGNS, POSTERS AND THE LIKE.
   No signs, plaques, posters or pictures shall be displayed by any individual,
whether a member of the Common Council or not, on the Council floor or upon a
Council member’s desk.
(Prior Code, § 30.19) (Ord. 3631, passed 4-28-1969)
§ 30.30 MEMBERS PRESENT REQUIRED TO VOTE.
   Every member of the Common Council who shall be present at any meeting, when
a question is put by the Chair shall be required to give his or her vote.
(Prior Code, § 30.20)
§ 30.31 AMENDMENT OF RULES.
   (A)   Sections
30.20 through
30.31 may be amended at any regular meeting of the Common Council by a majority
vote of the elected members of the Council.
   (B)   However, no amendatory ordinance shall be passed on the same day or at
the same meeting that it is introduced except by unanimous consent, and then
only in case there are present and voting at least 2/3 of all the elected
members of the Council.
(Prior Code, § 30.21)
§ 30.32 PUBLIC MEETINGS SIMULTANEOUS WITH COMMITTEE MEETINGS.
   Every public caucus or meeting of the Council shall be considered for all
purposes to be simultaneous meetings of all the committees of the Common
Council, and action on any matter referred to a committee may be taken by the
members of the committee during such caucuses or meetings of the Common
Council.
(Ord. 8668, passed 4-11-2005)
§ 30.33 OPENING PRAYER.
   The Common Council shall re-institute its practice of beginning each meeting
with a short invocation or prayer.
(Ord. 9257, passed 7-14-2014)
ORDINANCES AND RESOLUTIONS
§ 30.45 SPONSOR TO BE DESIGNATED IN ORDINANCE OR RESOLUTION.
   Every proposed ordinance, resolution and order considered by the Common
Council shall be sponsored by a member of the Common Council, except that the
Mayor may sponsor the annual salary ordinance or any amendment thereto and the
city budget ordinance or any amendment thereto. Any other ordinance, resolution
or order not having a sponsor set forth above may not be considered by the
Common Council.
(Prior Code, § 30.25) (Ord. 4715, passed 10-26-1981; Am. Ord. 7010, passed 1-
11-1988)
§ 30.46 APPROPRIATION OR TRANSFER OF FUNDS ORDINANCE.
   (A)   For every appropriation or transfer ordinance introduced before the
Common Council, the city official requesting the appropriation or transfer of
funds shall either appear in person or by personal representative on either the
first or final reading of the ordinance or submit in writing before the final
reading a detailed explanation of the need for passage of the ordinance with
which his or her proposed appropriation or transfer of funds is concerned.
   (B)   Such an ordinance shall not come to final passage until the
appropriate official has complied with the requirements of this section.
(Prior Code, § 30.26) (Ord. 3673, passed 4-13-1970)
§ 30.47 READING AND PASSAGE.
   (A)   Every ordinance shall receive 3 separate readings prior to its
passage. Resolutions shall receive 1 reading. The readings of all ordinances
and resolutions shall be by title only. Any Council member may request to have
the ordinances or resolutions to be read in its entirety. If there is any
inconsistency between state statutes and any ordinance setting out procedural
rules for the Common Council, the statute shall prevail. An ordinance may be
given final passage pursuant to the provisions of I.C. 36-4-6-13 which provides
as follows:
   Ordinance; two-thirds vote with unanimous consent of members present
   Sec. 13. (a) A two-thirds (2/3) vote of all the elected members, after
unanimous consent of the members present to consider the ordinance, is required
to pass an ordinance of the legislative body on the same day or at the same
meeting at which it is introduced.
   (b) Subsection (a) does not apply to a zoning ordinance or amendment to a
zoning ordinance that is adopted under I.C. 36-7.
   (B)   Ordinances and resolutions shall be prepared and a copy shall be in
the hands of all Council members at least 5 days prior to their presentation,
and shall be delivered to each Council member at his or her residence or place
of business by the designee of the Chief of Police. However, in case of
emergency, ordinances or resolutions may be presented and adopted at the time
of meeting, but only in case 2/3 of the elected members are present, and then
only by consent of 2/3 of the elected members.
(Prior Code, § 30.27) (Ord. 4292, passed 12-27-1976; Am. Ord. 4775, passed 8-
16-1982; Am. Ord. 7765, passed 1-23-1995; Am. Ord. 9126, passed 12-19-2011)
Statutory reference:
   Passage of ordinance on day of introduction, see I.C. 36-4-6-13
   Passage of ordinance requires majority vote, see I.C. 36-4-6-12
§ 30.48 VOTE ON FINAL PASSAGE.
   (A)   The vote on the final passage of any ordinance or resolution shall be
by calling the roll and recording the ayes and nays.
   (B)   Any 2 Council members may demand the ayes and nays be taken on any
question or motion, and when so demanded, the question shall be put and
recorded.
(Prior Code, § 30.28)
§ 30.49 CITY CLERK TO PUBLISH AND FILE.
   It shall be the duty of the City Clerk to cause all ordinances requiring
publication by law, to be published according to law immediately after their
passage. The City Clerk shall at the time procure the proper proof of the
publication of the ordinance and file and preserve the ordinance in his or her
office, with the other public documents of the city.
(Prior Code, § 30.29)
Statutory reference:
   Publication of ordinances, see I.C. 36-4-6-14
§ 30.50 COPY OF PENAL ORDINANCES TO BE DELIVERED TO POLICE CHIEF.
   Whenever any ordinance which provides a penalty for the violation thereof is
passed by the Common Council, approved by the Mayor, and published according to
law, it shall then be the duty of the City Clerk to deliver immediately to the
Chief of Police a certified copy of that ordinance in the form in which it was
so passed, approved and published.
(Prior Code, § 30.30)
§ 30.51 DEBATE.
   The sponsor of any ordinance shall be permitted to have the last word in any
debate or discussion concerning any ordinance, resolution or order.
(Prior Code, § 30.31) (Ord. 7023, passed 4-11-1988)
§ 30.52 ACTIONS REPORTED OUT OF COMMITTEE.
   The majority of the membership of any standing or special committees of the
Common Council is needed to report out any proposed favorable or unfavorable
action from the committee or special committee.
(Prior Code, § 30.32) (Ord. 7023, passed 4-11-1988)
§ 30.53 COUNCIL OFFICES.
   The offices of the Common Council shall consist of the Common Council
Chambers, Room 209, the Common Council Caucus Room, Room 205, and the small
hallway connecting the foregoing 2 rooms. The Common Council Caucus Room, Room
205, is the private office of the Common Council and shall not be used by any
person other than a member of the Common Council or an employee of the Common
Council and entry to the same shall be prohibited except by invitation of a
member or employee of the Common Council, except that matters concerning
routine maintenance, repairs and the like may be conducted by appropriate
personnel. The Caucus Room, Room 205, shall be open to the public 30 minutes
prior to the commencement of any meeting of the Common Council and at all times
in which a Committee of the Common Council is conducting a meeting in such
Caucus Room.
(Prior Code, § 30.33) (Ord. 7023, passed 4-11-1988)
§ 30.54 ORDINANCES AND RESOLUTIONS IN COMMITTEE FOR MORE THAN 1 YEAR.
   Any ordinance, resolution, order or other matter referred to a committee or
special committee of the Common Council and which is in such committee or
special committee for more than 1 year shall be considered to have failed
passage and adoption, unless the Common Council, by majority vote, agrees to
extend the time by which the committee or special committee may consider the
ordinance, resolution, order or other matter.
(Prior Code, § 30.34) (Ord. 7025, passed 4-12-1988)

§ 31.19 CITY CLERK.
   (A)   For provisions concerning the City Clerk, see I.C. 36-4-10-1 et seq.
   (B)   (1)   The City Clerk is authorized to appoint any employee of the City
Clerk’s office in an acting capacity to serve as Acting Chief Deputy and/or
Acting Office Manager whenever, in the City Clerk’s discretion, the permanent
employee in such position shall be absent for a period of 10 working days
annually because of vacation, medical or other reason.
      (2)   Any person so appointed shall receive additional compensation over
and above the compensation the appointee receives as an employee of the City
Clerk’s office equal to the stated compensation for the higher position to
which the person is appointed in an acting capacity. However, neither the City
Clerk nor the Chief Deputy City Clerk shall be eligible for additional
compensation. The additional compensation paid for service in an acting
capacity may only be paid from money available and otherwise unused in the
salary account of the City Clerk’s office. In no event shall the total acting
pay received by any employee, exceed the difference between the employee’s
present salary and that of the salary of the employee for whom 1 is serving in
an acting capacity.
   (C)   (1)   The City Clerk is authorized to appoint as Deputy City Clerks up
to 17 employees of the City Clerk’s office.
      (2)   Persons so appointed shall receive no additional compensation over
and above the compensation the appointees receive as an employee of the City
Clerk’s office.

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 32.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BOARD OF PUBLIC WORKS. The Board of Public Works and Safety of the city.
   PENSION BOARD. The Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund of the city.
(Prior Code, § 32.01)
§ 32.02 ESTABLISHMENT; DUTIES.
   There is hereby established a Police Department within the city. This
Department shall be charged with the duty of preserving the peace, protecting
life and property within the city, enforcing this code and all city ordinances
and regulations and performing those duties which may be imposed upon it by
ordinance or by provision of state law.
(Prior Code, § 32.02)
Statutory reference:
   Duties of City Police Department, see I.C. 36-8-3-10
§ 32.03 COMPOSITION.
   The composition of the city’s Police Department shall be regulated by city
ordinances, general orders and rules and regulations of the city’s Police
Department as promulgated and approved by the Board of Public Works and Safety.
(Prior Code, § 32.03) (Am. Ord. 7706, passed 7-11-1994)
§ 32.04 RANKINGS.
   The following shall be authorized ranks for sworn police employees of the
Police Department.
   (A)    Chief of Police;
   (B)    Assistant Chief of Police;
   (C)    Captain;
   (D)    Lieutenant;
   (E)    Sergeant;
   (F)    Corporal;
   (G)    Patroler, first class;
   (H)    Patrolperson, second class; and
   (I)    Probationary patrolperson.
(Prior Code, § 32.04) (Am. Ord. 7706, passed 7-11-1994)
§ 32.05 DISTRIBUTION AND ASSIGNMENT OF PERSONNEL.
   (A)   The distribution and assignment of the personnel of all ranks below
Chief shall be determined by the Chief of Police and the Board of Public Works
and Safety in accordance with the rules and regulations governing the Police
Department.
   (B)   The rules and regulations shall be promulgated by the Board of Public
Works and Safety.
   (C)   The structure, organization and deployment of the police force shall
be the responsibility of the Chief of Police, subject to the approval of the
Board of Public Works and Safety.
(Prior Code, § 32.05)
Statutory reference:
   Authority of Board of Public Works and Safety over Police Department, see
I.C. 36-8-3-1 et seq.
§ 32.06 DUTY TO INVESTIGATE ACCIDENTS ON PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   It shall be the duty of the Police Department to investigate accidents
involving death, personal injury or property damage in excess of $150 which
occur on privately-owned property.
(Prior Code, § 32.06) (Ord. 7336, passed 12-10-1990)
§ 32.07 MERIT SYSTEM.
   (A)   The Common Council hereby establishes a police merit system pursuant
to the provisions of I.C. 36-8-3.5.
   (B)   This section adopts and incorporates by reference the provisions of
I.C. 36-8-3.5-1 through I.C. 36-8-3.5-23.
(Prior Code, § 32.07) (Ord. 8403, passed 1-14-2001)
§ 32.08 COMMISSARY PROGRAM.
   (A)   There is hereby created and established by the Common Council a
Hammond City Jail Commissary Program.
   (B)   The Commissary Program will exist and operate out of the Hammond City
Jail. It shall be governed by written Police Department policies and procedures
and operated by a contract commissary service.
   (C)   A separate Jail Commissary Fund shall be established which shall be
separate from the General Fund. Money in the Commissary Fund does not revert to
the General Fund.
(Ord. 8843, passed 3-26-2007)
§ 32.09 USE OF CONFIDENTIAL FUNDS.
   The Police Department, by its Police Chief, is authorized to provide,
dedicate and utilize confidential funds located within the Police Department
budget, in accordance with the terms and conditions of Police Department
general orders concerning such funds.
(Ord. 9402, passed 2-12-2018)
EMPLOYMENT
§ 32.20 EMPLOYMENT QUALIFICATIONS.
   (A)   General qualifications for appointment as a member of the Police
Department shall be governed by I.C. 36-8-3.5-12.
   (B)   Additional requirements include the following:
      (1)   Applicant must be able to read and write the English language;
      (2)   Applicant must be at least 21 years of age or attain the age within
60 days of filing the application; and
      (3)   Applicant must be a good moral character.
   (C)   When and if a conditional offer of employment is made, applicant must
be able to meet the physical and mental requirements established by the Board
of Pension Trustees.
   (D)   The Police Department shall not fail or refuse to hire, or discharge
any individual, or otherwise discriminate against any individual with respect
to his or her compensation, terms, conditions or privileges of employment,
because of the individual’s race, color, religion, sex or national origin.
Neither shall the Department limit, segregate or classify its employees or
applicants for employment in any way which would deprive or tend to deprive any
individual of employment, because of the individual’s race, color, religion,
sex or natural origin.
(Prior Code, § 32.10) (Ord. 3322, passed 4-10-1961; Am. Ord. 3553, passed 2-13-
1968; Am. Ord. 4068, passed 1-13-1975; Am. Ord. 5045, passed 6-9-1986; Am. Ord.
7706, passed 7-11-1994)
Statutory reference:
   Maximum age for appointment, see I.C. 36-8-4-7
   Physical examination, see I.C. 36-8-4-7
   Residence required, see I.C. 36-8-4-2
§ 32.21 PROBATIONARY PERIOD.
   (A)   Every appointment to the Police Department shall be for a probationary
period of 1 year.
   (B)   If at any time during the probationary period the conduct or capacity
of the probationer is found to be unsatisfactory, as determined by the Board of
Public Works and Safety, upon the recommendation for discharge by the Police
Chief the probationer shall, without hearing and without right of appeal, be
notified in writing by the Board of Public Works and Safety that he or she will
not receive a permanent appointment, whereupon his or her employment shall
cease.
   (C)   Otherwise, retention of the probationer in service after the
expiration of the probationary period shall be equivalent to and shall
constitute his or her final and permanent appointment.
(Prior Code, § 32.12) (Ord. 3322, passed 4-10-1961; Am. Ord. 4963, passed 7-8-
1985)
§ 32.22 DISCHARGE OR SUSPENSION.
   All disciplinary actions regarding suspension, demotion or discharge shall
be taken in accordance with I.C. 36-8-3-4 and the city’s Police Department
rules and regulations as approved by the Board of Public Works and Safety.
(Prior Code, § 32.13) (Ord. 4392, passed 2-14-1978; Am. Ord. 7706, passed 7-11-
1994)
§ 32.23 PROMOTIONS.
   (A)   In order to be eligible for promotion, police officers shall have
completed the following number of years of continuous active service for
certain ranks:
      (1)   Sergeant: 6 years.
      (2)   Lieutenant: 8 years.
      (3)   Captain: 10 years.
      (4)   Assistant Chief: 12 years.
   (B)   This section shall not apply to the motor pool.
(Prior Code, § 32.14) (Am. Ord. 7706, passed 7-11-1994; Am. Ord. 8542, passed
2-9-2004)
Statutory reference:
   Promotion policy, see I.C. 36-8-4-6
§ 32.24 SALARY RATES AND CLASSIFICATIONS.
   (A)   Active members shall receive such salary as is set out in the annual
salary ordinance.
   (B)   An active member of the Department may not be required, except in the
case of a public emergency as determined by the city executive, to work more
than 6 days of 8 hours in 1 week, or more than an average of 48 hours per week
in 1 year. (See I.C. 36-8-4-8)
   (C)   An active member of the Department who works any time over 8 hours in
any shift or over 40 hours a week average, including court appearances shall be
compensated at the rate established in the annual salary ordinance.
   (D)   Upon completion of 8 continuous years of service with the Department
and subject to approval by the Board of Public Works and Safety, a first-class
patrol officer will obtain the rank of corporal for salary and wage purposes.
   (E)   Specialty pay for certain positions will be compensated at the rate
established in the annual salary ordinance.
   (F)    Longevity pay will be compensated at the rate established in the
annual salary ordinance.
(Prior Code, § 32.16) (Ord. 4336, passed 7-25-1977; Am. Ord. 4346, passed 8-8-
1977; Am. Ord. 4388, passed 1-10-1978; Am. Ord. 7706, passed 7-11-1994)
§ 32.25 PAYMENTS TO WIDOWS, DEPENDENTS OF DECEASED MEMBERS.
   Payments made under this section shall be governed by I.C. 36-8-6-1 et seq.
and I.C. 36-8-8-1 et seq.
(Prior Code, § 32.20) (Ord. 7706, passed 7-11-1994)
Statutory reference:
   Death benefits, see I.C. 36-8-6-9.8
POWERS AND DUTIES OF MEMBERS
§ 32.35 POWERS AND DUTIES OF MEMBERS.
   The powers and duties of the members of the city’s Police Department shall
be regulated by I.C. 36-8-4-1 et seq., the rules and regulations of the city’s
Police Department and all general orders of the Police Department as approved
and authorized by the Board of Public Works and Safety.
(Prior Code, § 32.25) (Ord. 7706, passed 7-11-1994)
FEES
§ 32.45 CITY JAIL BOOKING AND PROCESSING FEE.
   (A)    Any individual, who upon arrest for a criminal or civil matter,
including but not limited to a criminal or civil warrant, custodial arrest,
probable cause hold or surrender, and is thereby booked and processed at the
city jail, shall remit to the city jail, from his bond, commissary account or
other funds a $30 dollar city jail booking and processing fee.
   (B)   A receipt showing the collection of these funds shall be provided to
the arrestee or his designee. A copy of the city jail booking and processing
fee ordinance shall be posted in a conspicuous location in the booking area and
a copy of this ordinance shall be provided to the arrestee upon request.
   (C)   Any individual who has paid the city jail booking and processing fee
and is able to demonstrate that he/she was arrested without probable cause
(released with no charges filed); was acquitted; or arrested only on charges
that were dismissed for a lack of merit, as opposed to charges dismissed
pursuant to a plea in another cause, or under a supervision agreement, is
entitled to file a claim with the city for refund or reimbursement of the city
jail booking and processing fee, and request a hearing before the Board of
Public Works and Safety. In cases where arrestee is indigent, as determined by
the court upon examination under oath, the arrestee may additionally petition
for waiver, refund, or reimbursement of the city jail booking and processing
fee.
(Ord. 8702, passed 11-14-2005; Am. Ord. 8732, passed 2-13-2006; Am. Ord. 8784,
passed 9-11-2006; Am. Ord. 9167, passed 8-13-2012)
§ 32.46 ADMINISTRATIVE FEE FOR FINGERPRINT PROCESSING.
   (A)   Whenever the Police Department, for an employment application, a bar
application or other purposes (but not as part of a booking process),
fingerprints an individual, an administrative fee of $10 for city residents and
$15 for non-city residents shall be collected from the individual being
fingerprinted.
   (B)   The Police Department shall forward this administrative fee to the
City Controller, who shall deposit it into a non-reverting account.
(Ord. 8705, passed 11-14-2005)
§ 32.47 ACCIDENT REPORT FEE.
   The city is a participant in the State of Indiana’s Traffic Safety
Division’s Traffic Records Program, which utilizes an electronic crash report
submission system. Any person wishing a copy of an accident report may access
buycrash.com to obtain a copy of that report, the Police Department no longer
provides copies of these reports.
(Ord. 8746, passed 3-27-2006; Am. Ord. 9214, passed 6-25- 2013)
§ 32.48 ADMINISTRATIVE FEE FOR SALVAGE TITLE CHECK.
   (A)   Whenever the Police Department performs a salvage title check or the
associated paperwork on a vehicle, a fee of $100 shall be collected for each
vehicle processed.
   (B)   The Police Department shall forward this administrative fee to the
City Controller, who shall deposit said fee into the General Account.
(Ord. 8878, passed 9-11-2007; Am. Ord. 9158, passed 5-30-2012)
§ 32.49 ADMINISTRATIVE FEE FOR VEHICLE INSPECTION.
   Whenever the Police Department performs a vehicle inspection for an
application for a certificate of title, a fee of $5 shall be collected for each
vehicle as allowed under I.C. 9-17-2-12(e).
(Ord. 9660, passed 12-30-2024)

Editor’s note:
   The city also falls under the provisions of the Police Officers’ and

§ 33.01 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   For provisions concerning the Fire Department, see
Chapter 93.
(Prior Code, § 33.01)
§ 33.02 RESERVED.
§ 33.03 FIRST RESPONDER FIREFIGHTERS, EMT’S, AND AMBULANCES REQUIRED AT SPECIAL
EVENTS.
   (A)   This section shall apply to all special events, held or scheduled on
property of the civil city or Park Department, in which vehicular exhibition
events, circus events, or in which full body contact or dangerous exhibitions,
such as MMA, at which admission is charged and attendance can reasonably be
anticipated to exceed 100 persons.
   (B)   At all events as described in division (A), the sponsor of the event
is required, at a minimum, to hire a First Responder Firefighter and an EMT or
other unionized firefighting outfit to be present at the event.
   (C)   Where the special event involves a body contact sport, described below
in division (D), at least 1 ambulance on reserve or non-active status shall be
standing present at the site of the event.
   (D)   For the purposes of this section, the following are considered to be
body contact sports:
      (1)   Karate;
      (2)   Wrestling;
      (3)   Boxing;
      (4)   Martial arts;
      (5)   Basketball; and
      (6)   Other full-contact body sports, as determined by the Board of Park
Commissioners, excepting parks and recreation programs run by the Parks and
Recreation Department.
   (E)   The cost of compliance of this section shall be borne by the persons
sponsoring the event.
(Ord. 8108, passed 7-27-1998; Am. Ord. 9416, passed 9-24-2018)
Editor’s note:
   Ord. 8108 was subsequently vetoed by the Mayor on August 5, 1998. The
Mayor’s veto was overridden by the Common Council on August 10, 1998.

ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR PUBLIC FACILITIES
§ 34.001 POWERS AND DUTIES.
