GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 100.01 ADOPTION OF STATE MANUALS.
   (A)   Part VIII of the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices as adopted
by the U. S. Department of Transportation, Federal Highway Administration,
effective April l, 1977, shall be incorporated herein as a part of this chapter
and enforceable under the enforcement provisions of this chapter.
   (B)   The Indiana Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and
Highways as adopted by the state’s Highway Commission shall be incorporated
herein as a part of this chapter and enforceable under the enforcement
provisions of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 110.01) (Ord. 4486, passed 12-11-1978)
§ 100.02 ELECTRICITY RATES.
   (A)   In the event that the city shall enter into any contract with any
company for the maintenance of electric lights at any street crossings, all
railroad companies shall have all of the rights and privileges as to rates with
the company furnishing the city electric lights under the contract made for its
public street lighting.
   (B)   It shall be the duty of any person furnishing any lights to the city
to furnish electric lights at the crossings where lights or signals are to be
maintained, at and for the same prices furnished by the city for street
lighting.
(Prior Code, § 110.02)
Penalty, see § 100.99
§ 100.03 SERVICE OF CITATIONS.
   Citations for offenses against this chapter by a railroad corporation shall
be served upon any responsible local officer, freight agent or passenger agent
of the railroad by any police officer or court bailiff of the city.
(Prior Code, § 110.03) (Ord. 3665, passed 2-9-1970)
OPERATION
§ 100.20 SWITCHYARDS.
   The switchyards of the city shall be defined as follows.
   (A)   The Monon Switchyard shall be deemed to extend from the south city
limits to the south side of 165th Street.
   (B)   The Erie Switchyard shall be deemed to begin at the south side of
Douglas Street and extend south to the north side of Highland Street.
   (C)   The Nickel Plate Switchyards, commonly known as Osborne Yard, shall be
deemed to extend from the east side of Indianapolis Boulevard to the north side
of 165th Street and from the south side of 165th Street to the west side of
Osborne Avenue.
   (D)   The Indiana Harbor Belt and Michigan Central Switchyards, more
commonly known as the Gibson Yards, shall be deemed to extend from the west
side of Kennedy Avenue to the east side of Maywood Avenue.
   (E)   The IHB Switchyards between Cline Avenue and Kennedy Avenue shall be
deemed to extend from the east side of Kennedy Avenue to the west side of Cline
Avenue.
(Prior Code, § 111.10) (Ord. 3541, passed 9-11-1967)
Penalty, see § 100.99
§ 100.21 WARNING SIGNALS ON GATES REQUIRED.
   (A)   (1)   All railroads passing through any part of the city who maintain
safety gates at the intersection of their respective rights-of-way with any
public highway in the city at grade crossings shall equip all the gates with
electric lights or warning signals of sufficient power and intensity to warn
approaching vehicles or pedestrians that the gates are closed.
      (2)   The warning lights on the arms of the gates shall be operated and
kept at all times lighted whether the gates are open or closed between dusk and
dawn of each and every day of the year.
   (B)   All railroads operating in the city and having or using a railroad
crossing in the city are hereby required to maintain in continuous and proper
working condition all grade crossing equipment and safety devices so as not to
unnecessarily impede or adversely affect traffic or adversely affect the health
and welfare of the community.
   (C)   All railroads operating in the city and having or using a railroad
crossing shall be required to install all crossing equipment as required by §
100.01.
(Prior Code, § 111.11) (Ord. 4486, passed 12-11-1978)
Penalty, see § 100.99
§ 100.22 RESTRICTIONS ON TRAFFIC; EXCEPTION.
   (A)    (1)   Railroad traffic shall be prohibited between the hours of 6:30
a.m. and 8:30 a.m. and between the hours of 3:30 p.m. and 5:30 p.m. in the
following manner.
      (2)   Railroad traffic shall not obstruct, block or otherwise impede
vehicular traffic on any crossing within the city during these hours, except as
provided herein.
      (3)    Prohibited railroad traffic shall include, but not be limited to
the following.
         (a)   Traffic originating outside of and moving into the city
utilizing public streets for this movement within the hours set forth in this
section, when the traffic shall have as its next destination or stopping point
a point outside of the city.
         (b)   Traffic originating outside of and moving into the city
utilizing public streets for this movement within the hours set forth in this
section, when the traffic shall have as its next destination or stopping point
a point inside of the city.
         (c)   Traffic originating within the city to any other point within
the city over any public street or railroad crossing within the city within the
hours set forth in this section.
         (d)   Traffic originating inside of and moving outside of the city
utilizing public streets for this movement within the hours set forth in this
section, when the traffic shall have as its next destination or stopping point
a point outside of the city.
   (B)   Division (A) above shall not apply to those specific railroad trains
carrying passengers for hire and operating as interstate or intrastate common
carriers.
(Prior Code, § 111.12) (Ord. 3665, passed 2-9-1970)
Penalty, see § 100.99
§ 100.23 LIGHTS REQUIRED.
   Every locomotive engine, railroad car or train of cars, running in the
nighttime on any railroad track in the city, shall have and keep while so
running a brilliant and conspicuous light on the forward end of the locomotive
engine or train of cars, and in case any engine, car or train shall be run
backward at that time, the light shall be kept at the rear end thereof.
(Prior Code, § 111.13)
Penalty, see § 100.99
§ 100.24 SPEED.
   (A)   Locomotive engines moving in a northerly or southerly direction on any
railroad crossing 173rd Street, 165th Street, Douglas Street, and Hohman Avenue
in the city shall not exceed a speed of 50 mph at any street crossing between
173rd Street and 165th Street; shall not exceed a speed of 40 mph at any street
crossing between 165th Street and Douglas Street; and shall not exceed a speed
of 25 mph at any street crossing between Douglas Street and Hohman Avenue, all
inclusive.
   (B)   Locomotive engines moving in an easterly or westerly direction on any
railroad crossing Kennedy Avenue, Indianapolis Boulevard, Columbia Avenue, and
Calumet Avenue in the city shall not exceed a speed of 50 mph at any street
crossing between Kennedy Avenue and Cline Avenue; shall not exceed a speed of
40 mph at any street crossing between Kennedy Avenue and Columbia Avenue; and
shall not exceed a speed of 40 mph at any street crossing between Columbia
Avenue and Hohman Avenue, both inclusive.
(Ord. 4659, passed 3-9-1981)
   (C)   Locomotive engines moving in an easterly or westerly direction on any
railroad crossing Sheffield Avenue, Hohman Avenue and Calumet Avenue in the
city shall not exceed a speed of 25 mph across any of these streets.
(Prior Code, § 111.14)
Penalty, see § 100.99
§ 100.25 WATCHER REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any railroad company, conductor, engineer or any
other person managing any car, locomotive or train of cars to run the same
backward in or through the city without a watcher or other person on the rear
end of the car, locomotive or train, or to shove any car in the city by means
of locomotive engine power without a watchman on the forward end of the car.
(Prior Code, § 111.15)
Penalty, see § 100.99
§ 100.26 STANDING CARS.
   It is unlawful for any railroad company or any person operating or having
charge or control of any railroad train, railroad car or engine within the
city:
   (A)   To permit, allow or cause any train, railroad car or engine to stand
at any intersection of any street, sidewalk or alley, for a period longer than
5 minutes at any 1 time, without allowing vehicles and pedestrians to cross the
railroad tracks, except when necessary to comply with governmental safety
regulations or where the train, railroad car or engine cannot be removed by
reason of circumstances over which the railroad company has no control.
   (B)   To obstruct any intersection of any street, sidewalk or alley for a
period longer than 5 minutes at any 1 time by switching, without allowing
vehicles and pedestrians to cross the railroad tracks over any such street,
sidewalk or alley, except when necessary to comply with governmental safety
regulations or where the train, railroad car or engine cannot be removed by
reason of circumstances over which the railroad company has no control.
   (C)   This section shall not apply to trains, railroad cars or engines in
motion, other than those engaged in switching.
   (D)   This section is enacted to promote the public interest and welfare of
the residents of the city and those using its public streets, sidewalks and
alleys, not to control railroad safety, thus its enactment shall not supplant
current Indiana law governing “negligence” or the lack thereof by railroads,
their employees and/or agents at street, sidewalk and alleyway crossings.
(Prior Code, § 111.16) (Ord. 8169, passed 4-12-1999; Am. Ord. 8259, passed 4-
24-2000)
Penalty, see § 100.99
§ 100.27 CATTLE CARS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any railroad company owning and controlling
any railroad running through the city or any person in their employ to permit
cattle cars, which have been in recent use and are uncleaned, to stand on any
siding or sidetrack within the city for a longer period of four hours.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person owning or controlling a railroad
through the city or persons in their employ to remove the straw manure from a
cattle car and to clean the cars within the city. This section shall not apply
to the territory located east of Parrish Avenue and south of Fifteenth Avenue
in the city.
(Prior Code, § 111.17)
Penalty, see § 100.99
CONSTRUCTION OF TRACKS
§ 100.45 PERMISSION REQUIRED TO LAY TRACKS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to lay on or across any street, alley or
public place in the city any railroad track without first obtaining permission
from the Board of Public Works and Safety ratified by the Common Council of the
city.
(Prior Code, § 111.25)
Penalty, see § 100.99
§ 100.46 CONFORMITY WITH STREET GRADES REQUIRED.
   (A)   When any street or highway in the city is to be built and improved to
an established grade, then any person owning, constructing, maintaining or
operating any street railway over, across or along any street or highway in the
city shall conform all railway tracks, including switches, turnouts, spur
tracks and crossovers to the established grade.
   (B)   Whenever a contract shall be let for the building and improvement of
any street or highway in the city to an established grade and any street
railway track established grade, then the city shall notify, in writing, the
person owning or maintaining the tracks that the work necessary to conform the
tracks to an established grade shall be commenced within 15 days after the
service of the notice and completed as soon as reasonably possible.
   (C)   Whenever a contract has been let for the building and improvement of
any street or highway in the city to an established grade, and any street car
tracks running over, across or along the street do not conform to the
established grade, the City Engineer, upon request, shall furnish a grade and,
also, the lines of the street occupied by the tracks to the person maintaining
the tracks.
   (D)   All railroads operating in the city and having or using a railroad
crossing in the city are hereby required to maintain the street crossing grade
so as not to impede traffic or adversely affect traffic.
(Ord. 4486, passed 12-11-1978)
(Prior Code, § 111.26)
Penalty, see § 100.99
Statutory reference:
   Authority of Board of Public Works and Safety as to railroad crossing grade
separations, see I.C. 8-6-2.1-1 et seq.
§ 100.47 PERMISSION REQUIRED TO CHANGE TRACK ELEVATION ON HIGHWAY.
   It shall be unlawful for any railroad operating through, along, upon and
across any public highway in the city at grade to either raise or lower the
rails of the railroad at the point where the railroad intersects any highway
without first procuring from the Board of Public Works and Safety permission to
do so in writing.
(Prior Code, § 111.27)
Penalty, see § 100.99
§ 100.48 REMOVING TRACKS IN VIOLATION.
   (A)   Upon the direction from the Mayor or the Board of Public Works of the
city, the Street Commissioner of the city shall tear out any railroad track so
laid in violation of the provisions of this chapter, and remove the same from
any street, alley or public place on which it is found or has been laid.
   (B)   The Street Commissioner shall keep an itemized account for the expense
incurred by him or her in the tearing up and removal of tracks, and he or she
shall thereupon institute suit against the offending person for the recovery of
the expense.
(Prior Code, § 111.28)
Penalty, see § 100.99
§ 100.49 MATERIALS TO BE USED.
   It shall be the duty of all railroads or railroad companies operating a line
of railroads through the city to erect and construct all street crossings over
which their railroad crosses, with asphalt, concrete slabs or other materials
specified by the city for the full width of their right-of-way.
(Prior Code, § 111.29)
Penalty, see § 100.99
REPAIR OF STREETS AND SIDEWALKS
§ 100.65 AUTHORITY OF COMMON COUNCIL TO ORDER CONSTRUCTION OR REPAIR.
   (A)   Whenever any street or sidewalk crossing on property owned by any
railroad company shall be out of repair, the Common Council may, by resolution,
order the owner to construct a new sidewalk, repair, raise or lower the street
or sidewalk crossing and may also order that the width and riding quality of
the roadway surface at a grade crossing should, as a minimum, be restored to
correspond with the approaches to the crossing.
   (B) The Common Council shall in the resolution prescribe the time in which
the repairs shall be completed, material to be used therein, and the manner of
doing the repairs.
(Prior Code, § 111.35) (Ord. 4495, passed 2-12-1979; Am. Ord. 4531, passed 6-
25-1979)
§ 100.66 NOTICE.
   (A)   (1)   When the resolution provided for in §
100.65 has been passed by the Common Council, the City Clerk shall, as soon as
practicable thereafter, issue and cause to be served by the police force a
written notice informing the company or companies of the adoption of the
resolution, and that the resolution is filed in the Clerk’s office where it may
be inspected by them.
      (2)   This notice shall specify the time limited for making the new
construction or repair and a description of the street or sidewalk crossing to
be so repaired. In case the company is a nonresident of the city, the notice
shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the crossing or parts thereof.
      (3)   It shall be the duty of the company or companies to make the new
construction or repairs in the manner prescribed in the resolutions and within
the time limited therefor under the direction of the City Engineer and to his
or her satisfaction and acceptance.
   (B)   (1)   In case any street or sidewalk crossing shall be so out of
repair as to be dangerous for use, the Street Commissioner shall without action
of the Council, at once give a written notice to the company or companies in
case they are residents of the city and in case they are nonresidents of the
city or cannot be found, no notice shall be required to immediately repair the
street or sidewalk crossing.
      (2)   In case of failure to do so, the Street Commissioner shall cause
the new construction or repairs to be made, at once, under the direction of the
City Engineer and to his or her satisfaction and acceptance.
      (3)   Thereupon proceedings shall be had for the assessment of the costs
on the property and the collection of the costs as provided for in this
chapter.
(Prior Code, § 111.36) (Ord. 4495, passed 2-12-1979; Am. Ord. 4531, passed 6-
25-1979)
§ 100.67 FAILURE TO COMPLY; CONSTRUCTION OR REPAIR BY CITY.
   (A)   In case any company shall fail or refuse to comply with the
requirements of a resolution of the Common Council ordering the new
construction or repair of a sidewalk, the City Engineer shall notify the Street
Commissioner of the failure or refusal, and the Street Commissioner shall, as
soon as practicable, make the new construction or repairs specified and
required in the resolution under the direction of the City Engineer and to his
satisfaction and acceptance. In the event the Street Commissioner does not have
the necessary personnel or equipment available to make the new construction or
repairs, the City Engineer with the approval of the Board of Works may, in
accordance with the law, assign the work to a private contractor.
   (B)   The Street Commissioner shall report to the Common Council the costs
of the new construction or repair in detail, giving the name of the owner and a
description of the street or sidewalk crossing liable therefor and the amount
for which each is chargeable, and the certificate of the City Engineer attached
showing that the work has been properly done and brought to the established
grade.
(Prior Code, § 111.37) (Ord. 4495, passed 2-12-1979; Am. Ord. 4531, passed 6-
25-1979)
Penalty, see § 100.99
§ 100.68 CITY TO HAVE LIEN; ASSESSMENT AND COLLECTION OF COSTS.
   (A)   The city shall hold and have a lien on all lots and parts thereof
abutting on any street or sidewalk crossing so newly constructed or repaired by
the Street Commissioner or private contractor for the costs thereof; and the
lien shall begin at the time of the completion of the repairs.
   (B)   The Common Council shall assess the expenses by resolution on the lots
or property, respectively. Thereupon, the city shall demand payment from the
parties against whom the assessments shall be made.
      (1)   In case any of the owners of lots or property or parcels of ground
on which the assessments have been made shall fail or refuse, for the space of
20 days after the date of the assessment by the Common Council, to pay the
amount due by the company to the city, it shall be the duty of the County
Treasurer in behalf of the city, to file his or her affidavit in the Clerk’s
office of the city, stating that the whole or some part of the assessment
remains unpaid, showing the amount paid and the amount due and remaining
unpaid, and stating that the estimate thereof has been duly made and that work
estimated has been done according to the provisions of this chapter and the
resolution ordering the work.
      (2)   It shall be the duty of the City Clerk at the next regular meeting
of the Common Council to report the affidavit to the Council, whose duty it
shall be to cause a precept to be issued for the collection of the assessments
or unpaid balance thereof, in accordance with the provisions of state law.
(Prior Code, § 111.38) (Ord. 4495, passed 2-12-1979; Am. Ord. 4531, passed 6-
25-1979)
Penalty, see § 100.99
§ 100.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Where no specific penalty is provided, the violation of any provision
of this chapter shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000. Every day any
violation shall continue shall constitute a separate offense.
   (B)   Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate the provisions of §§
100.21 or
100.26 shall, upon conviction, be fined in any sum not to exceed $500.
(Ord. 4486, passed 12-11-1978)
   (C)   For each violation of §
100.26, defined as each separate stopping or switching of trains, railroad cars
or engines in violation hereof, a penalty consisting of a fine not exceeding
$2,500 shall be assessed, thus any person, firm or corporation who shall
violate the provisions of §
100.26 shall, upon conviction, be fined in any sum not to exceed $2,500.
However, no railroad conductor or engineer acting under the rules or orders of
the railroad company or its supervisory personnel may be fined for thereby
violating §
100.26.
(Ord. 8259, passed 4-24-2000)
(Prior Code, § 111.99)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 101.001 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   PROPERTY OWNERS. The titleholder of any property, any person claiming an
interest in the property, occupant or tenant thereof, and further including
those exercising any right of control over the property.
   PUBLIC STREETS AND WAYS.
      (1)   The portion of a paved roadway to the curbs at the edges thereof;
      (2)   The portion of a paved public way without curbs between the extreme
edges of the dedicated public way;
      (3)   The portion of a public way which is unpaved but lying within a
dedicated right-of-way; and
      (4)   All portions of a dedicated alley denominated or used as an alley,
excluding those portions of a right-of-way normally used as an alley but lying
entirely within private property.
(Prior Code, § 101.01) (Ord. 3729, passed 3-22-1971)
§ 101.002 ENFORCEMENT.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police and the Code Enforcement
Commissioner to see to the enforcement of each and all of the provisions of
this chapter.
   (B)   Whenever there is any obstruction in any street or alley or sidewalk,
each and every police officer shall endeavor to remove the obstruction, and if
the obstruction cannot readily be removed, then any police officer aware of the
condition shall report the condition to the Department of Public Works and
Safety, and the Department shall remove the obstruction.
(Prior Code, § 101.02) (Am. Ord. 8435, passed 7-22-2002)
§ 101.003 PLACING DEBRIS ON STREETS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No person shall be allowed to place any building material or any other
material whatsoever on any of the public streets, sidewalks or alleys of the
city without a special permit.
   (B)   Property owners are hereby prohibited from moving onto public streets
or ways any debris, refuse, objects or snow at any time.
(Prior Code, § 101.03) (Ord. 3729, passed 3-22-1971)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.004 REMOVAL OF SOD AND THE LIKE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to dig, remove or carry away or cause to
procure the same to be done any sod, stone, earth, sand, soil or gravel from
any street, alley or public ground in the city, without first having obtained
permission in writing from the city.
(Prior Code, § 101.04)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.005 CAR WASHES.
   Car washes are hereby prohibited from depositing water or ice onto public
streets or ways at any time. Car washes are required to keep sufficient
abrasives on hand, at all times, which must be applied to slippery pavement,
developing as a result of the use of the car wash, for a distance of 3 blocks
in any direction from the car wash.
(Prior Code, § 101.05) (Ord. 3729, passed 3-22-1971)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.006 PARADE PERMITS.
   (A)   No procession or parade containing 200 or more persons or 50 or more
vehicles, except the forces of the United States Army or Navy or the military
forces of the state and the forces of the Police and Fire Departments, shall
occupy, march or proceed along any street except and in accordance with a
permit issued by the Chief of Police and any other regulations as are set forth
herein which apply.
   (B)   Permission for all parades must be obtained from the Chief of Police
or the Board of Public Works and Safety, and these officials may designate the
routes of the parade.
(Prior Code, § 101.06)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.007 KEEPING SIDEWALKS CLEAR.
   The occupant or owner, if there is no occupant, of each and every tenement
building or lot in the city fronting upon any improved sidewalk shall clear the
sidewalk in front of the tenement building or lot of snow or ice by 10:00 a.m.
of each day and keep the sidewalk clear of snow or ice.
(Prior Code, § 101.07)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.008 GRATINGS TO BE SET FLUSH.
   All gratings, cellar doors, scuttle covers and similar coverings shall be
set flush with the sidewalk in which they occur and shall conform to the grade
and slope thereof.
(Prior Code, § 101.08)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.009 CROSS GUTTERS.
   Shallow gutters may be constructed across sidewalks to convey clean storm
water from spoutings, but no gutter shall be more than 2 inches in depth and
shall have sloping sides not less than 4 inches in width. When there is
sufficient depth, vitrified tile shall be used under the sidewalk. Where there
is not sufficient depth, gutters may be constructed in sidewalks if the gutters
are provided with flat stone or iron coverings set flush with the sidewalk, or
without covering as above provided and not otherwise.
(Prior Code, § 101.09)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.010 INJURING SIDEWALKS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to break or otherwise injure any
sidewalk or to keep or leave any cellar door or grating of any vault on any
highway or sidewalk or suffer the same to be left open or kept open in front of
his or her premises so as to endanger life or limb.
(Prior Code, § 101.10)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.011 DUTY OF POLICE TO REPORT DEFECTS.
   It shall be the duty of all police officers to report to the Department of
Public Works and Safety all defects in sidewalks, and in case of accident, they
shall report the accident to the Law Department, together with the names of any
witnesses to the accident, if known to them.
(Prior Code, § 101.11)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.012 CLOSING OF PUBLIC STREETS AND ALLEYS.
   Pursuant to I.C. 36-9-6 and such other applicable law as is appropriate, the
exclusive power to order the closing of any public street and alley in the city
for more than 10 days is vested in the Common Council. The determination to
close any public street or alley shall be made in the form of an order or
resolution.
(Prior Code, § 101.12) (Ord. 5052, passed 7-29-1986)
§ 101.013 OBSTRUCTION OF PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to encumber or obstruct any
street, alley, sidewalk, public ground, building or parkway in the city with
any material, substance, vehicle or thing whatsoever.
(Prior Code, § 101.13) (Ord. 5083, passed 10-27-1986)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.014 HARDBALL/BASEBALL PROHIBITED AT FORSYTHE SQUARE.
   (A)   No person shall play hardball/baseball at Forsythe Square (119th
Street and Warwick Avenue) in the city.
   (B)   Any violation of this section may be punished by a fine of not more
than $25.
(Prior Code, § 101.14) (Ord. 7503, passed 7-27-1992)
§ 101.015 SOLICITATION BY PEDESTRIANS ON OR ABOUT PUBLIC STREETS OR WAYS.
   The following guidelines shall be met by organizations requesting permission
to solicit funds on public thoroughfares:
   (A)   There shall be no solicitation of funds, donations or other gratuities
or sale of items by any pedestrian on, upon or adjacent to the public streets
and ways of the city to or from the operators of occupants of motor vehicles
being driven upon those streets and ways, except as provided in division (B) of
this section. The sale of items may occur adjacent to the public streets only
if the seller is a registered and license business and such sale is occurring
in front of or adjacent to the licensed business’ regular place of operation.
   (B)   Solicitation shall be authorized by the Board of Works on the
following basis:
      (1)   Such shall only be permitted on the second and fourth Thursday,
Friday and Saturday during the months of April, May, June, July, August,
September and October;
      (2)   Such shall be limited to formally organized philanthropic, service
and your organization which originate in the city;
      (3)   Such shall be limited to 1 organization per day on a first come,
first serve basis;
      (4)   Only intersections with median :strips shall be used for
solicitation of funds or donations or other gratuities;
      (5)   Organizations shall provide proof of insurance naming the City, as
additional insured in minimum amounts of $500,000 per person and $1,000,000 per
incident; and
      (6)   In addition to the requirements set forth in this division (B)(6),
divisions (B)(1) through (B)(4), those organizations shall make public
application with the Chief of Police, who will forward the request to the Board
of Public Works and Safety for approval, at least 4 weeks prior to the date
requested; shall not solicit prior to 8:00 a.m., or after 4:00 p.m.; persons
involved shall wear reflective vests and shall not impede traffic; any person
involved under the age of 18 shall be accompanied by an adult sponsor over the
age of 21; and the party requesting the date for the organization shall provide
a telephone number and list of locations to be worked at.
   (C)   It shall be the responsibility of the Police Department, assisted by
the Code Enforcement Department to enforce the provisions of this section.
(Prior Code, § 101.15) (Ord. 7509, passed 8-10-1992; Am. Ord. 8623, passed 11-
15-2004)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.016 SALES OR DISTRIBUTION OF LITERATURE ON PUBLIC STREETS OR PROPERTY.
   (A)   No person shall sell any merchandise or distribute any literature or
flyers on any street within the city, on any traffic island or median in the
city or on public or private property within 200 feet of any intersection in
the city.
   (B)   This section in no way modifies the licensing provisions of
Chapter 122, “Peddlers, Hawkers and Transient Vendors” and those provisions
shall remain in full force and effect. This section shall not be applicable to
adult newspaper hawkers selling newspapers on Sunday or other periodical/
newspaper vending machines which do not obstruct motorists’ views or otherwise
detract from public safety and welfare.
   (D)   This section does not or shall not be applicable to the Hammond Fire
Department or the Hammond Firefighters’ Union seeking donations of charitable
cause on any day of the week.
   (E)   Newspapers and the firefighters must go before the Board of Public
Works and Safety to get a proper permit, whether it’s for the sale of
newspapers or for their fundraising efforts.
   (F)   Violations of this section shall be enforced by the Police or Code
Enforcement Departments pursuant to the general penalty §
10.99.
(Prior Code, § 101.16) (Ord. 7522, passed 8-24-1992; Am. Ord. 8621, passed 11-
16-2004; Am. Ord. 8735, passed 2-27-2006)
§ 101.017 ALLEYS; LOITERING PROHIBITED.
   (A)   In the interest of public safety, no individual shall loiter in any
city alley.
   (B)   In the interest of public safety, scrapping, scavenging, collecting,
removing, whether on foot or with a vehicle, any scrap or recyclable material
placed on a city alley line or city street is prohibited. This prohibition does
not include pick-ups done by the city, sanitary district, appliance delivery
service, or by a commercial waste hauler for multifamily units or businesses,
or by a not-for-profit group that is picking up donations at the request of a
city resident.
   (C)   Individuals possessing a one-year scavenger license, issued prior to
the adoption of this section, shall be permitted to scavenge until the
license's expiration on December 31, 2012. However, after passage of this
section, no further scavenger licenses shall be issued by the City Controller.
   (D)   This section may be enforced by the Police Department and or the Code
Enforcement Department. Violations of this section will be fined as provided in
§
10.99 of this code.
(Ord. 8816, passed 12-11-2006; Am. Ord. 8982, passed 3-9-2009; Am. Ord. 9165,
passed 7-23-2012)
§ 101.018 UTILITY RELOCATION.
   On every roadway or public project for which utilities must be moved,
cleared, relocated or buried, a representative of said utility company must
appear at the preconstruction meeting and state with reasonable certainty, the
time line under which said utilities will be moved, cleared, relocated or
buried. Such time line and plan must be done to the satisfaction of the project
engineer and City Engineer. Failure to follow this time line, without good
cause, will constitute a violation, with penalty as provided per §
10.99.
(Ord. 8811, passed 11-13-2006)
SLAGS AND CINDERS
§ 101.030 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (A)   Any person desiring to haul or deposit or dump the substances
regulated by this subchapter shall make application in triplicate to the City
Controller for a permit to haul, deposit, or dump the substances, which
application shall state, among other things, the following information.
      (1)   The name of the person desiring the permit;
      (2)   The route of travel of the trucks or other vehicles when loaded;
      (3)   The gross weight of the vehicles when loaded;
      (4)   A description of the substances to be hauled, deposited or dumped;
      (5)   The boundaries of the area in which the substances will be
deposited or dumped;
      (6)   The approximate amount of the substances which will be hauled,
deposited or dumped;
      (7)   The calendar period of time during which the substances will be
hauled, deposited or dumped; and
      (8)   The material which the applicant proposes to use to cover the
substances, if a cover is required, the thickness of the cover, the vegetation
cover planting to be used, if required, and any other information as may be
required.
   (B)   It shall be the duty of the City Controller to present a copy of the
application together with other information, as he or she may have, to the
Board of Public Works and Safety and to the city’s Plan Commission, who shall
determine the propriety of issuing the permit. The Board of Public Works and
Safety shall determine whether any public street or alley would be damaged by
the hauling or any citizens may be adversely affected or damaged in their
property rights by the hauling, depositing or dumping sought to be permitted.
The Plan Commission shall determine if the depositing or dumping sought to be
permitted is consistent with the master plan for the orderly development of the
city and appropriate for the present and future land use. The findings and
recommendations of the Board of Public Works and Safety and the Plan Commission
on the propriety of issuing the permit shall be transmitted to the Common
Council.
   (C)   (1)   When the application for a permit under this subchapter is
approved by the Board of Public Works and Safety and by the Plan Commission, as
provided in this subchapter, the permit shall not be issued or become effective
unless and until the permit is ratified by the Common Council by ordinance,
upon which a public hearing shall be held at a Common Council meeting after
advertisement, as required by law.
      (2)   After advertisement, public hearing and ratification by ordinance,
the Controller shall issue a permit setting out therein the name of the
permittee and describe the substance to be hauled, deposited or dumped, the
weight of the trucks when loaded and their route of travel and designate the
place where the substances are to be deposited or dumped, by appropriate
description, and the approximate amounts of the substances to be hauled,
deposited or dumped, the material, amount and depth of the cover, if required,
and all other details enumerated in division (B) above, and transmit a copy of
the permit to the designated enforcement agencies.
      (3)   The City Controller shall retain a copy of the permit and
application in a file available to public inspection for a time of not less
than 3 years from date of issue.
(Prior Code, § 101.20)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.031 PERMIT NONTRANSFERABLE.
   No permit issued under this subchapter shall be transferable and no permit
shall be applicable to any other place, substance or amount than the same shall
appear in the permit.
(Prior Code, § 101.21)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.032 TERM OF PERMIT.
   No permit shall be valid for a period of time longer than 1 year from date
of issue, and renewal applications shall follow the same procedure as
prescribed for initial applications.
(Prior Code, § 101.22)
§ 101.033 TRUCK REQUIREMENTS.
   All trucks hauling the substances regulated by this subchapter over the
streets within the city shall be equipped with bodies sufficiently tight to
prevent the spilling of the substances over the streets or alleys of the city,
shall not be loaded to a height which will endanger the contents falling onto
the street and if the substances being hauled are in whole or in part of a size
or density which can be windblown, the load must be completely covered with a
tarpaulin or other effective cover or closure or the truck will be in violation
of this subchapter.
(Prior Code, § 101.23)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.034 COVERING OF SUBSTANCES.
   When it appears to the Board of Public Works and Safety, the Plan Commission
or the Common Council that within an area wherein the substances regulated in
this subchapter are to be deposited or dumped that it is proper to cover the
substances or plant with a vegetation or both to prevent being carried or moved
by the elements, the permit shall specify the material and manner in which the
substances shall be covered or planted.
(Prior Code, § 101.24)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.035 UNAUTHORIZED HAULING A NUISANCE.
   Unauthorized hauling over public streets or depositing or dumping within the
city of slag, cinders, refuse, rubble or debris or any like substance which, in
whole or in part, is to be and is hereby declared to be a public nuisance.
(Prior Code, § 101.25)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.036 EXEMPTIONS.
   The provisions of this subchapter shall not apply to the hauling,
depositing, or dumping for streets, alleys, driveways or public improvements.
(Prior Code, § 101.26)
§ 101.037 ENFORCEMENT.
   The Police Department, the City Engineer and the City Building Inspector are
jointly and independently designated and authorized to enforce this subchapter,
and it shall be their duty to do so.
(Prior Code, § 101.27)
§ 101.038 REMEDIES.
   Any designated enforcement official or any aggrieved person may institute a
suit for mandatory injunction in any court of competent jurisdiction to
restrain any person from violating the provisions of this subchapter, or may
institute a suit to effect the removal of substances dumped or deposited in
violation of this subchapter and if not promptly removed by the offender, it
may be removed at the direction of the court and the cost of removal may be
assessed against the violator.
(Prior Code, § 101.28)
CONSTRUCTION OF SIDEWALKS
§ 101.055 PERMIT; COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   (A)   In all cases, except where sidewalks are to be laid in accordance with
the provisions of special improvement resolutions of the Board of Public Works
and Safety, it shall be unlawful for any person to construct, lay or rebuild
any sidewalk on any portion of the public streets or alleys of the city without
first having obtained a permit to do so from the Board of Public Works and
Safety, specifying the work to be done.
   (B)   The construction, laying or rebuilding of a sidewalk shall be done in
strict compliance with the permit required by division (A) above, and the
specifications prepared for the construction of sidewalks adopted by the Board
of Public Works and Safety.
(Prior Code, § 101.35)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.056 APPLICATION FOR GRADE.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, reconstruct or make
a general repair of any sidewalk or make any excavation in any street or
sidewalk for the purpose of constructing, reconstructing or making a general
repair of any sidewalk without having first applied to the City Engineer in
writing for the grade of the sidewalk.
   (B)   It shall be the duty of the City Engineer to furnish the applicant
with a blank application for the grade, wherein shall be specified the date of
the application, the location of the premises on which the sidewalk abuts by
number and street or lot and addition, the kind of sidewalk proposed to be
constructed, reconstructed or repaired, and the date when the applicant
proposes to begin the work.
   (C)   The application shall be signed by the property owner, and the person
or contractor doing the work.
(Prior Code, § 101.36)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.057 CITY ENGINEER TO FURNISH PLANS, SPECIFICATIONS AND GRADE.
   (A)   Upon the filing of an application for grade at the office of the City
Engineer, he or she shall furnish the applicant with a copy of plans and
specifications for the making of the improvement, and shall, as soon as
possible thereafter, furnish the applicant with stakes showing the required
grade for the sidewalk. Before any excavation or work is begun on the sidewalk,
it shall be the duty of the City Engineer and he or she shall have the right to
inspect the material to be put in the construction, reconstruction or repair of
the sidewalk. The material shall conform to the plans and specifications to the
satisfaction of the City Engineer.
   (B)   The grades for sidewalks shall be furnished by the City Engineer when
a permit has been granted for the construction of the sidewalk. It shall be
unlawful for any person to build or assist in building any sidewalk where no
grade has been established, without first obtaining a grade therefor from the
City Engineer, or contrary to any grade which may be obtained from the City
Engineer, or shall build or assist in building any sidewalk contrary to any
grade which may have been established by the Board of Public Works, or contrary
to any of the provisions of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 101.37)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.058 CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS.
   (A)   The grade of all sidewalks of the city shall conform to the grade of
their corresponding streets.
   (B)   All sidewalks constructed in this city shall be installed on the lot
line and not otherwise, and it shall be unlawful to construct any sidewalk in
any manner other than as designated in this chapter.
   (C)   All sidewalks built or constructed in the city shall be of flagstone,
concrete or mosaic tile. It shall be unlawful to build or construct a sidewalk
of any other kind of material. Prism glass may be inserted into sidewalks where
the walks are laid over vaults and areaways.
   (D)   All sidewalks shall be so constructed that, when completed, the top
surface shall coincide with the grade of the space between the curb line and
the street line, which grade shall be a uniform incline from the street line
toward the curb line, with a fall of 1 inch to every 3 feet.
(Prior Code, § 101.38)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.059 WORK TO BE DONE PROMPTLY.
   Construction, reconstruction or general repair work on sidewalks, when
begun, shall be prosecuted with due diligence until completed. After completion
of the work, the contractor or person doing the work or the person causing the
work to be done shall clean up and remove all surplus dirt, debris and material
therefrom. During the progress of the work all necessary and proper lights and
safeguards shall be placed to prevent accidents to passers-by.
(Prior Code, § 101.39)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.060 INSPECTION; NOTICE OF IMPROPER WORK.
   (A)   After the construction, reconstruction or general repair of any
sidewalk, it shall be inspected by the City Engineer. If made and completed in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter and the plans and specifications
of the Engineer to the satisfaction of the Engineer, the sidewalk shall be
accepted by him or her on behalf of the city and he or she shall furnish the
contractor or the person doing the work a certificate to that effect. No person
shall be liable to any person doing the work for the work until the sidewalk is
completed and the certificate is furnished.
   (B)   In case the construction, reconstruction or general repair of a
sidewalk is not completed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and
the plans and specifications of the City Engineer, the City Engineer shall
serve a notice on the property owner or person causing the work to be done
specifying wherein the work is defective and require the person to remedy the
defects within 10 days from notification.
   (C)   In case the person shall fail or refuse to comply with the notice, the
City Engineer shall report to the Common Council at the next regular meeting
thereof, the name of the property owner together with a description of the
premises. The Common Council shall have the right by resolution to order the
reconstruction and repair of the sidewalk to comply with the plans and
specifications and the provisions of this chapter and enforce the costs thereof
against the premises as provided by §§
101.064 and
101.065.
(Prior Code, § 101.40)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.061 CONSTRUCTION OR REPAIR BY CITY AT INTERSECTION.
   Whenever any sidewalk is in process of construction or general repair, that
part of the sidewalk embraced in the street or alley intersections shall be
constructed or repaired by the city in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter at the same time and of the same material as any of the adjacent walks.
(Prior Code, § 101.41)
§ 101.062 ASSESSMENTS FOR NEW SIDEWALKS.
   All new sidewalks, when ordered by the Common Council, shall be constructed
and the cost thereof assessed and collected as provided by law for the making
of street and alley improvements.
(Prior Code, § 101.42)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.063 SPECIFICATIONS FOR DRIVEWAYS.
   Where driveways are to be built across the sidewalk space, they shall
conform to the sidewalk grade and shall be 9 inches in depth, consisting of a
layer 2 inches in depth.
(Prior Code, § 101.43)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.064 ORDERS TO REPAIR.
   (A)   Whenever any sidewalk or curbing in front of or adjoining the lot or
parts thereof owned by any person shall be out of repair, the Common Council
may, by resolution, order the owner to repair, raise, lower or relay the
sidewalks or curbing.
   (B)   The Common Council shall in the resolution prescribe the time in which
these repairs shall be completed, material to be used therein, and the manner
of doing the repair.
   (C)   When the resolution has been passed by the Common Council, the City
Clerk shall, as soon as practicable thereafter, issue and cause to be served by
the Police Force a written notice informing the person of the adoption of the
resolution, and that the resolution is filed in the City Clerk’s office where
it may be inspected by them. The notice shall specify the time limited for
making the repairs and a description of the sidewalk or curbing to be so
repaired. In case the person is a nonresident of the city, the notice shall be
posted in a conspicuous place on the lot or parts thereof. It shall be the duty
of that person to make the repairs in the manner prescribed in the resolutions
and within the time limited therefor under the direction of the City Engineer
and to his or her satisfaction and acceptance.
   (D)   In case any sidewalk shall be so out of repair as to be dangerous for
use, the Street Commissioner shall without action of the Council, at once, give
a written notice to the person in case he is a resident of the city and in case
he is a nonresident of the city or cannot be found, no notice shall be required
to immediately repair the sidewalk. In case of failure to do so, the Street
Commissioner shall cause the repairs to be made, at once, under the direction
of the City Engineer and to his or her satisfaction and acceptance. Proceedings
shall be had for the assessment of the costs on the property and the collection
of the costs as provided for in this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 101.44)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.065 REPAIRS BY CITY.
   (A)   In case any person shall fail or refuse to comply with the
requirements of a resolution of the Common Council ordering the repair of a
sidewalk, the City Engineer shall forthwith notify the Street Commissioner of
the failure or refusal, and the Street Commissioner shall, as soon as
practicable, make the repairs specified and required in the resolution under
the direction of the City Engineer and to his or her satisfaction and
acceptance.
   (B)   The Street Commissioner shall report to the Common Council the costs
of the repair in detail, giving the name of the owner and a description of the
lot or premises liable therefor and the amount for which each is chargeable,
and the certificate of the City Engineer attached showing that the work has
been properly done and brought to the established grade.
   (C)   The city shall hold and have a lien upon all lots and parts thereof
abutting on any sidewalk or curbing so repaired by the Street Commissioner for
the costs thereof, and the lien shall begin at the time of the completion of
the repairs.
   (D)   The Common Council shall assess the expenses by resolution upon the
lots, respectively, and shall demand payment from the parties against whom the
assessments shall be made. In case any of the owners of lots or parcels of
ground on which these assessments have been made shall fail or refuse, for the
space of 20 days after the date of the assessment by the Common Council, to pay
this amount thereof due by that person to the city, it shall be the duty of the
County Treasurer in behalf of the city, to file his or her affidavit in the
Clerk’s office of the city, stating that the whole or some part of the
assessment remains unpaid, showing the amount paid and the amount due and
remaining unpaid and stating that the estimate thereof has been duly made and
that work estimated has been done according to the provisions of this chapter
and the resolution ordering the work. It shall be the duty of the Clerk at the
next regular meeting of the Common Council to report the affidavit to the
Council, whose duty it shall be to cause a precept to be issued for the
collection of the assessments or any unpaid balance thereof, in accordance with
the provisions of state law.
(Prior Code, § 101.45)
Statutory reference:
   Assessment liens, see I.C. 36-9-36
SIDEWALK OPENINGS AND EXCAVATIONS
§ 101.080 EXCAVATION PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION.
   (A)   No person shall make any excavation of any character in any of the
public streets, sidewalks or alleys within the city without a special permit.
   (B)   All special permits for excavating or placing building material or any
other material whatsoever in any of the public streets, sidewalks or alleys of
the city shall be issued by the Street Commissioner.
   (C)   Applications for all special permits covered by this chapter shall be
made in writing on blanks furnished by the city, the application must show the
exact location of the proposed excavation or the proposed place the building
material or any other material is to be put, and the Street Commissioner shall
keep a record of all permits granted by him or her.
(Prior Code, § 101.50)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.081 SAFETY REGULATIONS.
   (A)   The person who receives the permit shall cause the excavation to be
refilled and placed in the same condition before dark of the day on which the
excavation is made, or shall move the building material or other material of
any kind so placed. If for any reason it shall be impossible to do so, proper
platforms, bridges or safeguards for the passage of pedestrians and vehicles
shall be placed over the excavations or material, and so maintained until the
work is completed and the material is removed. Suitable red lights and guards
shall be placed at night, so as to warn the public of danger.
   (B)   As soon as the excavations are filled in or the material is removed,
the person to whom has been granted a special permit shall immediately notify
the Street Commissioner of completion of the work and the Street Commissioner
shall immediately inspect the place. If found to be in proper repair he or she
shall immediately issue a release to that person, and if the work is not done
properly, then the Street Commissioner shall immediately require the person,
firm or corporation to put it in proper condition. If the person fails or
refuses to do so at once he or she shall upon conviction be fined in the sum
hereafter set out.
(Prior Code, § 101.51)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.082 COVERS FOR ALL OPENINGS REQUIRED.
   (A)   No person shall make any excavation in or near any street, alley or
sidewalk so as to endanger the life or limb of any person or animal passing
thereby without having secured by curbing or in some manner the excavation from
the liability.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or insecurely fix or
cause or procure or suffer or permit to be removed or to be insecurely fixed,
so that the grate or covering can be moved in its bed, any grate or covering of
any coalhole, vault, chute or other opening in any street, sidewalk or other
public place. Nothing contained in this section shall prevent the owner or
occupant of the building, with which the coalhole, vault or chute shall be
connected, from removing the grate or covering for the proper purpose of the
openings, provided, that he or she encloses the opening or aperture and keeps
the opening or aperture enclosed while the grate or covering shall be removed
with a strong box or curb at least 24 inches high, firmly and securely made.
Also, he or she shall not remove the grate or covering until after sunrise of
any day and shall replace the grate or covering before 1/2 hour after sunset.
   (C)   Every opening in any vault or coalhole or aperture in the sidewalk
over the coal or vault shall be covered with a substantial iron plate with a
rough surface to prevent accidents, and the entire construction of the
coalholes and vaults shall be subject to the direction and supervision of the
Board of Public Works and Safety.
      (1)   Whenever any coalhole, vault or elevator under any sidewalk or any
aperture constructed in any sidewalk, is not covered or secured as provided in
division (C) above, or, in the opinion of the Board of Public Works and Safety,
the covering is unsafe or inconvenient for the public travel, then the Board
may order the coalhole, vault, or elevator to be placed in a safe condition
satisfactory to the Board.
      (2)   If the coalhole, vault or elevator is not placed in a safe
condition within 2 days from the service of notice on the owner or person in
possession of the premises, the Board may make the changes and the expense
thereof shall be paid by the owner or person in possession of the premises.
(Prior Code, § 101.52)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.083 LIABILITY.
   (A)   The owner or person in possession of the abutting premises in front of
which a coalhole, vault or other opening in a sidewalk is permitted shall be
held responsible to the city for any and all damage to persons or property in
consequence of any defect in the construction of the vault, coalhole or other
opening or for allowing the opening to remain out of repair. The owner shall be
required to keep the vault, coalhole or other opening and its walls and
coverings in good order at all times.
   (B)   The person in possession of any premises abutting on a vault, coalhole
or other opening in a sidewalk shall be held responsible to the city for any
and all damages occasioned to persons or property in consequence of the opening
being left exposed and uncovered or the covering thereof being left insecure or
unfastened.
(Prior Code, § 101.53)
Penalty, see § 10.99
BREAKING AND OPENING CURBS
§ 101.095 APPLICABILITY OF SUBCHAPTER.
   This subchapter shall not affect the right of an owner, upon permission
first secured, to break or open a curb for any driveway where the property is
not used for commercial purposes.
(Prior Code, § 101.60)
§ 101.096 APPLICATION AND DRAWING REQUIRED.
   When the owner or lessee of any real estate within the city shall desire to
break or open any curb along any street in this city for the purpose of
permitting vehicles to drive across any sidewalk and into any filling station
or place where a public business is conducted, it shall be the duty of the
owner or lessee to make appropriate application to the Board of Public Works
and Safety for permission to do so and to accompany the application with a
plate or drawing indicating the exact location of the proposed opening and
breaking of curb and indicating the number of these openings proposed.
(Prior Code, § 101.61)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.097 SUPERVISION BY CITY ENGINEER.
   The breaking and opening of curbs shall be under the direct supervision of
the City Engineer and shall be made, if permission granted and bond tendered,
strictly in accordance with the orders of the Engineer.
(Prior Code, § 101.62)
Penalty, see § 10.99
PARKWAYS
§ 101.110 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   COMMERCIAL DISTRICTS. Those districts designated “LB” and “GB” in the zoning
code of the city and amendments thereto.
   INDUSTRIAL DISTRICTS. Those districts designated “LI” and “HI” in the zoning
code of the city and amendments thereto.
   PARKWAY. The area as may be within or between 2 public streets and the area
between the sidewalk and extending to the curb or edge of the hard-surfaced
roadway.
   PAVING. Any substance, including but not limited to, concrete, asphalt,
cinders, gravel or slag, forming an artificial roadway or wearing surface, but
not including grass.
   RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS. Those districts designated “A,” “B,” “C” and “D” in
the zoning code of the city and amendments thereto.
(Prior Code, § 101.70) (Ord. 3721, passed 12-28-1970)
§ 101.111 PAVING ACROSS PARKWAYS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to pave across or upon any portion of the public
parkways within areas zoned residential, as designated in the zoning code.
   (B)   No person shall hereafter pave across or upon any portion of the
public parkways within commercial or industrial areas as designated in the
zoning code of the city. However, upon approval by the Board of Park
Commissioners of the Department of Public Parks, permission may be granted for
the paving of public parkways where the benefit thereof will be to the citizens
and the city.
(Am. Ord. 4240, passed 8-9-1976)
(Prior Code, § 101.71) (Ord. 3721, passed 12-28-1970)
Penalty, see § 10.99
BUILDERS
§ 101.120 LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of
building or constructing sidewalks within the city, or for persons, other than
themselves, under contract without first having procured a license to engage in
that work from the City Controller.
   (B)   Any person desiring a license to engage in the business of
constructing and building sidewalks for other people under contract within the
city shall make application, in writing, for a license to the Board of Public
Works, setting out in the application the full name and residence of the
applicant, if an individual, and the full name and residence of each of the
partners, if a partnership, and, if a corporation, the name and place of the
corporation.
(Prior Code, § 101.80)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.121 LICENSE FEE.
   Upon the approval of the bond required by §
101.123, the Board of Public Works and Safety shall approve the application for
a license by endorsing their written approval thereon, in writing, and the City
Controller shall issue to the applicant an annual license to engage in the
business of constructing and building sidewalks, as provided in this section,
upon the payment by the applicant to the city of the annual license fee in the
sum of $25.
(Prior Code, § 101.81)
§ 101.122 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   It shall be the duty of the Mayor, upon complaint of the Board of Public
Works and Safety or the City Engineer, to revoke the license of any person
licensed under the provisions of this subchapter if the licensee is an habitual
violator of the provisions of this code or other ordinances of the city
relating to the construction of sidewalks and the conditions upon which the
license has been granted.
(Prior Code, § 101.82)
§ 101.123 BOND.
   The applicant for a license under this subchapter shall file with the Board
of Public Works and Safety a bond with sureties to be approved by the Board of
Public Works in the sum of $5,000 for the purpose of indemnifying the city
against damages on account of accidents during the construction of any
sidewalks built by the person producing the license. The licensee shall repair
and replace any defective sidewalk for a period of 5 years from the time of
completion of any sidewalk constructed by the licensee after written notice, as
provided in this subchapter. This bond shall not have less than 2 resident
freehold sureties or an approved surety company, all of which shall be to the
approval of the Board of Public Works and Safety.
(Prior Code, § 101.83)
§ 101.124 FAILURE TO DO WORK.
   (A)   In the event any person fails to replace or rebuild, as may be
required by this subchapter, any defective sidewalk laid by that person by
private contract upon 15 days written notice from the Board of Public Works and
Safety to the licensee and his or her sureties on his or her bond, then the
Board of Public Works and Safety shall cause the work, required to be done in
the notice, to be done by letting a contract for the work after 1 week’s
publication, or in case the city has let an annual contract for the building of
sidewalks, the city shall have an action on the bond against the licensee and
sureties for the most of any work.
   (B)   In the event the licensee shall fail or refuse to pay the cost of any
work let under the contract or done by the annual contractor for the city, then
the licensee shall be suspended from receiving any further permits or doing any
further work until he or she has paid for all the defective work which has been
replaced under any contract, as provided in this subchapter.
(Prior Code, § 101.84)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.125 IMPRESSIONS IN SIDEWALK.
   It shall be the duty of all persons licensed under the provisions of this
subchapter upon the completion of any sidewalk constructed by the licensee to
stamp an impression upon each end of every sidewalk so constructed by the
licensee with the name of the licensee and the date of completion of the
sidewalk.
(Prior Code, § 101.85)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.126 REPLACING DEFECTIVE WORK.
   In case a builder shall construct a sidewalk contrary to the provisions of
this chapter, or fail to come up to the requirements, or in an unworkmanlike or
defective manner, the Board of Public Works and Safety shall give written
notice to the person to rebuild or replace the walk within 15 days after the
receipt of the notice. The notices shall be sent only between April 1 and
November 1 of every year.
(Prior Code, § 101.86)
Penalty, see § 10.99
PROCEDURE FOR VACATION OF PUBLIC WAYS AND PLACES
§ 101.140 REQUIREMENTS OF STATE LAW TO BE MET.
   Anyone petitioning the Common Council for a vacation of a public way or
place shall adhere to the requirements of I.C. 36-7-3-12 and all other
applicable law.
(Prior Code, § 101.90) (Res. 4878R2, passed 4-9-1984)
§ 101.141 PETITION TO CITY ENGINEER.
   (A)   Prior to the filing of a petition by any person with the Common
Council seeking a vacation, that person shall present the proposed petition to
the City Engineer. The City Engineer shall review the proposed petition, seek
the recommendation of the affected utilities or other land owners as the City
Engineer deems appropriate, and submit his or her report or recommendation on
the proposed vacation to the Common Council prior to or simultaneous with the
filing of the petition for vacation.
   (B)   The Common Council shall not act on any petition for vacation filed
with it and not first presented to the City Engineer as described in division
(A) above.
(Prior Code, § 101.91) (Res. 4878R2, passed 4-9-1984)
CONSTRUCTION TRAFFIC REGULATIONS
§ 101.155 PERMIT REQUIRED TO TRAVEL OFF OF DESIGNATED TRUCK ROUTES.
   Any construction company doing construction work within the city who cannot
access that work from designated truck routes only and will need to use local
residential streets must obtain a permit through the Board of Public Works and
Safety prior to commencing the construction project. All contractors must
notify the Board of Public Works and Safety and must obtain permission from the
Board prior to closing access to any public street for any period of time.
(Prior Code, § 101.95) (Ord. 7364, passed 4-22-1991)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.156 PERMIT PROCESS; BOND.
   The permit process will include defining the route to be used by the
contractor and his or her subcontractors and providing a bond to the city to
cover the potential damage that the heavy equipment may cause to city property.
The bond shall be in an amount equal to potential damage to the streets and
public rights-of-way and will be established by the Board of Public Works and
Safety on a case-by-case basis based upon the dollar amount of potential
damage. In establishing the amount of the bond, the Board shall consider the
recommendation of the City Engineer. The permit shall designate the route to be
traversed and contain any other restrictions or conditions deemed necessary by
the Board for the proper protection of city property.
(Prior Code, § 101.96) (Ord. 7364, passed 4-22-1991)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 101.157 APPLICATION AND COMPLIANCE.
   A contractor or construction company undertaking any current job within the
city must apply within 14 days of the passage of Ord. 7364 for a permit in
order to be in compliance with this subchapter. Nothing in this subchapter
shall be construed to relieve a contractor of obligation to fully repair all
damage caused to public property.
(Prior Code, § 101.97) (Ord. 7364, passed 4-22-1991)
Penalty, see § 10.99
NUISANCES HINDERING OR IMPEDING TRAFFIC
§ 101.165 PROHIBITED CONDUCT.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, organization, group, corporation,
property owner, tenant, or business to impede or interfere with vehicular or
pedestrian traffic by engaging in any behavior, display, promotion, event,
advertisement, sale, conduct or activity on any public sidewalk, alley,
easement, right-of-way, roadway, drive way, curbs, or private property
immediately adjacent to above public property. Such interference constitutes a
nuisance to traffic and is prohibited by this subchapter.
   (B)   Examples of such prohibited conduct include, but are not limited to:
      (1)   Causing or allowing any projectiles, objects, materials,
substances, debris, persons, animals or vehicles to enter a lane of traffic
from a sidewalk, alley, curb, easement, driveway, parking lot, right-of-way or
private property immediately adjacent to public property.
      (2)   Within 300 feet of any lane of traffic or intersection a nuisance
is created by any excessive noise, bullhorns, sports horns, fixed or moving
beacon lights, spot lights, search lights, flashing carnival lights, portable
lights on trailers, discharge of water, garbage or the emission of smoke,
steam, dry ice, or any substance whose release would prevent a motorist from
being able to hear emergency sirens, other vehicle horns, shouts from
pedestrians, or could obstruct vision or distract a driver traveling on the
road in a lane of traffic.
      (3)   Reduction of available customer or staff parking by fixed
structures, movable structures, displays, tents, trailers, promotions, or
additional vehicles which causes customer traffic to back up into or obstruct
vehicular traffic on any street or lane of traffic.
      (4)   Persons wishing to conduct activity listed supra, must petition to
the Board of Public Works and Safety prior to the event, and must outline in
detail the date, location, times, nature and scope of the activity planned, the
level of liability insurance possessed, and what specific traffic control,
health, visibility, sound and safety precautions will be implemented to insure
the safety and well being of the citizens of Hammond.
      (5)   Each day a nuisance is in existence is a separate offense, and the
city is authorized to issue citations or request any lawful court action to
abate the nuisance created.
(Ord. 8935, passed 6-3-2008)
Penalty, see § 10.99
