pilings or columns so that the bottom of the lowest horizontal structural
member of the lowest floor (excluding the pilings or columns) is at or above
the FPG. The pile or column foundation and structure attached thereto must be
anchored to resist flotation, collapse, and lateral movement due to the effects
of wind and water loads acting simultaneously on all building components.
      (1)   Water loading values used must be those associated with the base
flood.
      (2)   Wind loading values used must be those required by applicable state
or local building standards; or in the absence of applicable state or local
building standards, those determined according to American Society of Civil
Engineers 7-16, Minimum design loads and associated criteria for buildings and
other structures, or equivalent standard.
      (3)   A registered professional engineer or architect must develop or
review the structural design, specifications, and plans for the construction,
and must certify that the design and methods of construction to be used are in
accordance with accepted standards of practice for meeting the provisions of
this section.
      (4)   New construction and substantial improvements must have the space
below the lowest floor either free of obstruction or be constructed with non-
supporting breakaway walls, open wood latticework, or insect screening intended
to collapse under wind and water loads without causing collapse, displacement,
or other structural damage to the elevated portion of the building or
supporting foundation system.
      (5)   For purposes of this section, a breakaway wall must have a design
safe loading resistance of not less than 10 and no more than 20 pounds per
square foot.
      (6)   Use of breakaway walls that exceed a design safe loading resistance
of 20 pounds per square foot, either by design or where so required by local or
state codes) may be permitted only if a registered professional engineer or
architect certifies that the design proposed meets the following conditions:
         (a)   Breakaway wall collapse must result from a water load less than
that which would occur during the base flood; and
         (b)   The elevated portion of the building and supporting foundation
system must not be subject to collapse, displacement, or other structural
damage due to the effects of wind and water loads acting simultaneously on all
building components, structural and nonstructural.
            1.   Water loading values used must be those associated with the
base flood.
            2.   Wind loading values used must be those required by applicable
state or local building standards; or in the absence of applicable state or
local building standards, those determined according to American Society of
Civil Engineers 7-16, Minimum design loads and associated criteria for
buildings and other structures, or equivalent standard.
      (7)   Any enclosed space below the lowest floor shall be used solely for
parking of vehicles, building access, or storage.
      (8)   (a)   Placement or substantial improvement of manufactured homes
must comply with §
153.44.
         (b)   Recreational vehicles must either:
            1.   Be on site for fewer than 180 consecutive days;
            2.   Be fully licensed and ready for highway use; or
            3.   Comply with §
153.44.
(Ord. 9588, passed 12-27-2022) Penalty, §
153.99
§ 153.44 STANDARDS FOR SUBDIVISION AND OTHER NEW DEVELOPMENTS.
   (A)   All subdivision proposals and all other proposed new development shall
be consistent with the need to minimize flood damage.
   (B)   All subdivision proposals and all other proposed new development shall
have public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical, and water
systems located and constructed to minimize flood damage.
   (C)   All subdivision proposals and all other proposed new development shall
have adequate drainage provided to reduce exposure to flood hazards.
   (D)   In all areas of special flood hazard where base flood elevation data
area not available, the applicant shall provide a hydrologic and hydraulic
engineering analysis that generates base flood elevations for all subdivision
proposals and all other proposed new development (including manufactured home
parks and subdivisions), which is greater than the lesser of 50 lots or 5
acres, whichever is less.
   (E)   All subdivision proposals shall minimize development in the SFHA and/
or limit density of development permitted in the SFHA.
   (F)   All subdivision proposals shall ensure safe access into/out of SFHA
for pedestrians and vehicles (especially emergency responders).
   (G)   Streets, blocks lots, parks and other public grounds shall be located
and laid out in such a manner as to preserve and utilize natural streams and
channels. Wherever possible the floodplains shall be included within parks or
other public grounds.
(Ord. 9588, passed 12-27-2022) Penalty, see §
153.99
§ 153.99 PENALTY.
   Failure to obtain a floodplain improvement location permit in the SFHA or
failure to comply with the requirements of a floodplain improvement location
permit or conditions of a variance shall be deemed to be a violation of this
chapter. All violations shall be considered a common nuisance and be treated as
such in accordance with the provisions of the zoning ordinance for the City of
Hammond (
Chapter 158 herein) as may be amended from time to time. All violations shall
be punishable by a fine not exceeding $1,000.
   (A)   A separate offense shall be deemed to occur for each day the violation
continues to exist.
   (B)   The City of Hammond Plan Commission shall inform the owner that any
such violation is considered a willful act to increase flood damages and
therefore may cause coverage by a standard flood insurance policy to be
suspended.
   (C)   Nothing herein shall prevent the city from taking such other lawful
action to prevent or remedy any violations. All costs connected therewith shall
accrue to the person or persons responsible.
(Ord. 9588, passed 12-27-2022)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 154.01 SHORT TITLE.
   This chapter shall be known as the Hammond Heating, Ventilating and Cooling
Code.
(Prior Code, § 154.01) (Ord. 4880, passed 4-23-1984)
§ 154.02 BOARD OF EXAMINERS.
   (A)   Board created, officers designated. There is hereby created a board of
heating, ventilating, and cooling examiners (HVAC) which shall consist of 7
members to serve 2 year terms starting with the date of passage of the
ordinance codified herein, and shall be referred to herein as the HVAC Board of
Examiners. Membership of the Board shall consist of:
      (1)   The Building Commissioner;
      (2)   Heating Inspector;
      (3)   Two members to be appointed by the President of the Hammond Common
Council and serve at his or her pleasure;
      (4)   An employee of the Building Department who shall serve as secretary
for the board;
      (5)   One lay members who are residents of Hammond;
      (6)   One licensed heating, ventilating and cooling contractor. The
Building Commissioner shall be the Chairperson of the Board of Examiners and
the presence of 4 members shall constitute a quorum. The actions of the Board
shall be by majority vote of those present at the meeting. All members of the
Board must be Hammond residents.
   (B)   Meetings of Board. Meetings of the Board of Examiners shall be on the
first Tuesday of the months of January, April, July, and October in each year.
Special meetings of the Board may be held at the call of the Chairman when
deemed necessary, provided that five days written notice be given each member.
Notice shall be deemed given when deposited in the United States mail, properly
addressed, with first class postage affixed thereto.
   (C)   Compensation. Each member of the Board if present at the meeting shall
be compensated for his or her time as per Executive Order 15-32.
(Prior Code, § 154.02) (Ord. 4880, passed 4-23-1984; Am. Ord. 9339, passed 3-
28-2016)
§ 154.03 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BOARD. Unless otherwise designated shall mean the Board herein created.
   BOARD OF PUBLIC WORKS AND SAFETY. The Board of Public Works and Safety of
the city.
   CODE. The Indiana Mechanical Code as from time to time amended.
   CORPORATION. Those entities created under the authority of the laws of a
state within the United States but shall not include municipal corporations nor
governmental agencies.
   FIRM. The same meaning as partnership.
   HEATING, VENTILATING AND AIR CONDITIONING SYSTEMS. All devices for heating,
cooling, humidifying, dehumidifying or ventilating all or parts of any public
or private building and shall include source to appliance, wiring and all parts
thereof.
   PARTNERSHIP. A voluntary association between 2 or more persons on any
business or venture together upon the terms of mutual participation in its
profits or losses.
   TRADESTYLE. A name used in trade to designate a particular business of
certain individuals considered somewhat as an entity.
(Prior Code, § 154.03) (Ord. 4880, passed 4-23-1984)
§ 154.04 ADOPTION OF UNIFORM MECHANICAL CODE BY REFERENCE.
   (A)   The provisions of the 1979 Uniform Mechanical Code, all appendixes,
additions, deletions and future adoptions by the state shall be incorporated by
reference as fully as if set out at length herein.
   (B)   Three copies of the Uniform Mechanical Code are filed in the office of
the City Clerk.
(Prior Code, § 154.04) (Ord. 4932, passed 12-17-1984)
LICENSES
§ 154.15 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   All persons before installing, making changes in or upon, or repairing any
heating, ventilating or air conditioning system, shall obtain a heating
contractor’s license or any further license or permit required hereunder.
(Prior Code, § 154.10) (Ord. 4880, passed 4-23-1984)
Penalty, see § 154.99
§ 154.16 LICENSING OF HEATING, VENTILATING, AND COOLING CONTRACTORS.
   (A)   Application for registration as heating, ventilating, and cooling
contractor, hereafter referred to as a “heating contractor”, shall be made to
the City Controller on a form furnished by him or her for such purpose.
   (B)   The form shall require the following information:
      (1)   Name, age, business and home address of applicant;
      (2)   A list of past associations with any business, firm, partnerships
or corporation engaging in heating, ventilating and cooling work within the
State of Indiana and/or Illinois;
      (3)   The name or names of any firm, business, partnership or corporation
by who applicant is currently employed or for whom he or she is an officer or
in which he or she owns any interest;
      (4)   The name or names and home addresses of each owner and officer of
each business, firm, partnership or corporation referred to in division (B)(3)
above; and
      (5)   If the applicant is to have his or her license used on behalf of a
corporation, the name of such corporation. A heating contractor shall in all
instances be a natural person of the age of 18 or more.
(Prior Code, § 154.11) (Ord. 4880, passed 4-23-1984)
§ 154.17 LICENSING FOR CORPORATIONS.
   (A)   Every corporation doing business within the city in heating,
ventilating and cooling, shall have a licensed heating contractor as a bona
fide officer or employee of such corporation and who shall at all times be in
actual charge of heating, ventilating and cooling work done by such
corporation. Additionally, every corporation shall obtain a license certificate
in its name prior to doing business in the city. The license certificate shall
be issued upon application on a form provided by the City Controller’s office,
containing the following information.
      (1)   Name of corporation, date and state of incorporation;
      (2)   Name and home address of each officer and shareholder of the
corporation;
      (3)   The name or names of each tradestyle used by the corporation;
      (4)   The name of an agent at an address who will unequivocally accept
certified mail on behalf of the corporation; and
      (5)   The name of its licensed heating contractor.
   (B)   For purposes of this chapter, DOING BUSINESS shall mean:
      (1)   Having supplied or contracted to supply services rendered or to be
rendered or goods or materials furnished or to be furnished by this city within
the calendar year;
      (2)   Advertising in any publication regularly circulated within the
city, including but not limited to phone directories, newspapers and magazines,
within the calendar year; and
      (3)   Offering or having offered to do that delineated in division (B)(1)
above.
   (C)   Anything herein to the contrary notwithstanding these provisions shall
apply only to corporations engaged in erection, installation, alteration,
repairs, relocation, replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of
ventilating, heating, or cooling systems and are not intended to apply to
corporations engaged solely in the manufacture or resale of equipment within
the city and not to municipal corporations or other governmental agencies.
(Prior Code, § 154.12) (Ord. 4880, passed 4-23-1984)
Penalty, see § 154.99
§ 154.18 LICENSING OF FIRM OR PARTNERSHIP.
   Any firm or partnership shall be licensed in the name of such firm or
partnership upon application, provided, such firm or partnership shall have a
licensed heating contractor as a bona fide member or employee of such firm or
partnership, who shall at all times be in actual charge of work done by such
firm or partnership.
(Prior Code, § 154.13) (Ord. 4880, passed 4-23-1984)
Penalty, see § 154.99
§ 154.19 EXAMINATION.
   (A)   Before a license shall be issued to a HVAC contractor, the applicant
shall be required to submit to and pass an examination as to his or her
qualifications and fitness to install, maintain and/or repair heating,
ventilating and cooling equipment. Such examination shall be given under the
direction of the Board of Examiners.
   (B)   The initial fee for a HVAC contractor’s exam under this chapter shall
be $100. Examinations shall be practical in nature and shall fairly test the
ability of the applicant.
   (C)   The application for license shall be made at least 1 week prior to the
exam date, which shall be the regular meeting date of the Board.
   (D)   Any person obtaining a HVAC contractor’s license following the
issuance of a stop work order for failure to be licensed, shall pay an
additional $250 in addition to the initial fee at the time of receiving a
license.
   (E)   Any contractor who fails the examination for his or her license and is
required to re-test must pay a $50 re-examination fee for each re-test. Persons
who fail to show for a scheduled test will be considered as having failed the
test. All persons and companies operating as HVAC contractors who fail the test
given to them for the specific type of work they wish to perform, may retake a
similar test, but the number of re-tests is limited to 2. No contractor or
company may take the same test more than 3 times in a calendar year.
   (F)   The full annual fee must be paid, regardless of when a license is
issued and there will be no proration of fee, nor refund of fee upon revocation
or expiration of license.
(Prior Code, § 154.14) (Ord. 4880, passed 4-23-1984; Am. Ord. 9202, passed 3-
25-2013) Penalty, see §
154.99
§ 154.20 CONTRACTORS LICENSED AS OF ADOPTION.
   All heating contractors duly licensed at the time of the adoption of this
chapter shall be automatically licensed under the provisions hereunder without
submitting to an examination.
(Prior Code, § 154.15) (Ord. 4880, passed 4-23-1984)
§ 154.21 TERMINATION OF SERVICES.
   Upon termination of the services of the licensed heating contractor on
behalf of a corporation, firm or partnership, the operations of the
corporation, firm or partnership shall cease immediately, and it shall be
unlawful to continue work in progress unless and until a licensed heating
contractor is again associated with the corporation, firm, or partnership in
the manner required by this chapter. In the event of the death or physical
disability of a licensed heating contractor, a temporary certificate of
operation may be applied for as herein delineated, allowing the corporation,
firm or partnership to operate until the next scheduled meeting of the Board of
Examiners.
(Prior Code, § 154.16) (Ord. 4880, passed 4-23-1984)
§ 154.22 TEMPORARY LICENSE OF OPERATION.
   (A)   Anything herein to the contrary notwithstanding, a heating contractor
may use his or her license on behalf of more than 1 corporation, firm, or
partnership without complying with limitations above, under the following
conditions:
      (1)   One, but not more than 1 firm, corporation or partnership for which
his or her license is used has experienced the death or physical disability of
the heating contractor under whose license it has operated;
      (2)   He or she is in compliance with the terms of this chapter with
regard to any and all other firms, corporations or partnerships operating under
his or her license;
      (3)   He or she notifies the Controller’s office within 5 days of the
occurrence of the qualifying event, pays all required fees; and
      (4)   Certifies that he or she will be responsible for all work going on
by the corporation, firm or partnership.
   (B)   A temporary certificate of operation shall be valid from the date of
issuance until the next scheduled meeting of the Board of Examiners.
(Prior Code, § 154.17) (Ord. 4880, passed 4-23-1984)
§ 154.23 RESERVED.
§ 154.24 ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.
   (A)   The Examining Board shall issue a license to applicants successfully
passing an examination and/or upon fulfillment of the other requirements herein
set forth. The Board shall waive examinations to any presently licensed heating
contractors in the city.
   (B)   Anything to the contrary herein notwithstanding a license shall be
denied if:
      (1)   The application is for a contractor’s license and it appears that
the individual is in violation of a stop- work order pursuant to state laws; or
in engaging in unethical conduct, fraud or deceit in the performance of any
function of this trade; or has obtained a license or any renewal thereof by
fraud, falsehood or misrepresentation.
      (2)   The application is for a license for a corporation and a sole
shareholder or corporate officer has engaged in conduct described in division
(B)(1) above.
      (3)   The application is for a license for a firm or partnership and a
partner has engaged in conduct described in division (B)(1) above.
(Prior Code, § 154.19) (Ord. 4880, passed 4-23-1984)
§ 154.25 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   (A)   The Heating Contractor’s Board of Examiners shall be empowered to hear
complaints from the general public, or inspectors, relative to any violations
of the HVAC Code or sections of this chapter by licensed contractors or other
adverse conditions resulting from work performed by a licensed contractor. The
Board may take the necessary appropriate action or make necessary
recommendations to other municipal departments, agencies or boards of the city
government, to correct any adverse conditions resulting from inferior,
fraudulent or un-workmanlike work performed by an contractor licensed under
this chapter.
   (B)   The Heating Contractor’s Board of Examinations may deny an application
for a new or recommend the denial of a renewal of a license issued under this
chapter.
   (C)   The Heating Contractor’s Board of Examiners or Building Commissioner,
may recommend to the Mayor the suspension or revocation of any license issued
under this subchapter when the contractor is guilty of fraud,
misrepresentation, negligence, or violation of any section of the Municipal
Code, or any work not done in a workmanlike manner.
(Prior Code, § 154.20) (Ord. 4880, passed 4-23-1984; Am. Ord. 9205, passed 3-
25-2013)
§ 154.26 APPEALS.
   The decision of the Mayor made pursuant to § 154.25 may be appealed to the
Lake Superior or Circuit Court within 30 days of the decision on the license.
(Prior Code, § 154.21) (Ord. 4880, passed 4-23-1984; Am. Ord. 9205, passed 3-
25-2013)
§ 154.27 LICENSE NON-TRANSFERABLE.
   No license or renewal thereof, shall be assignable or transferable.
(Prior Code, § 154.22) (Ord. 4880, passed 4-23-1984)
§ 154.28 LICENSE FEES.
   (A)   The annual fee for an HVAC contractor’s license under this subchapter
shall be $200. The annual license fee for each annual renewal of a license
shall be $100 if renewed within 30 days of expiration. The Heating Contractor’s
Board of Examiners, upon good cause, may recommend the non-renewal of any
contractor’s license to the Mayor.
   (B)   Licenses renewed 30 days after expiration, shall be subject to an
additional late fee of $100. Licenses which have been expired for 180 days or
longer are no longer valid, and a contractor with an expired license will have
to take a HVAC contractor’s exam to become re-licensed.
(Prior Code, § 154.28) (Ord. 4880, passed 4-23-1984; Am. Ord. 9202, passed 3-
25-2013)
PERMITS
§ 154.40 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to replace, install or to make
substantial repair to any forced heating, wet heat, central air conditioning
units or appurtenances thereto within the city without first obtaining a
permit. Any person, contractor, or company desiring a mechanical permit for
work to be performed in the city shall, at the time the permit is issued
therefor, pay to the City Controller, a fee for their portion of the contracted
price of the project, as required in this section.
   (B)   This subchapter shall apply to homeowners performing work at occupied
residences and shall also apply to landlords performing work on leased
premises.
(Prior Code, § 154.30) (Ord. 4880, passed 4-23-1984; Am. Ord. 9660, passed 12-
30-2024)
§ 154.41 ISSUANCE OF PERMIT.
   (A)   A permit or permits to do the work above- described must be obtained
from the Building Commissioner of the city. Before a permit is issued, a
diagram of the premises and an estimate of type of heating system to be used,
and sufficient information showing that all provisions of the code are being
complied with, including the details of the mechanical devices for moving of
forced warm air, wet heat and/or central air conditioning systems, shall be
filed with the Building Commissioner. Permission to install shall not in any
manner constitute an approval if the installation of the same until after
inspection of same has been made to the satisfaction of the Building
Commissioner.
   (B)   Prior to issuing a permit to homeowners and landlords, the Building
Commission shall satisfy himself or herself that the applicant is competent to
perform the work for which the permit is requested.
   (C)   All applicants for a permit for the installation of, or major repair
to, a new central heating or central air conditioning unit shall also obtain an
electrical permit before works begins.
(Prior Code, § 154.31) (Ord. 4880, passed 4-23-1984)
§ 154.42 PERMITS NOT REQUIRED.

   At the time of hiring, the City Planner must have the following
qualifications.
   (A)   Hold a bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university;
   (B)   Have done undergraduate or graduate work in planning or related
fields;
   (C)   Have at least 2 years of experience in working for planning firms or
governmental organizations involved specifically with planning; and
   (D)   Be eligible for membership in the American Institute of Certified
Planners.

   (B)   The maps, drawings and other descriptive material enumerated in the

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 156.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (A)   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   PLUMBING CONTRACTOR. Any person or any of his or her representatives engaged
in plumbing.
   (B)   The definitions set out in I.C. 25-28.5-1-2 shall apply to this
chapter.
(Prior Code, § 156.01) (Ord. 3947, passed 11-26-1973)
§ 156.02 ADOPTION OF STATE PLUMBING RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Generally. The standards, rules, tests, charts, maps and regulations
as set forth in Volume III of the Plumbing Rules and Regulations of the State
Administrative Building Council and all future supplements and amendments
thereto, are hereby incorporated into this chapter, except to the extent that
this chapter or amendments thereto shall be in conflict, in which event this
chapter or ordinances amendatory thereof shall prevail.
   (B)   Filing and availability of copies. At least 2 copies of Volume III of
the Plumbing Rules and Regulations of the State Administrative Building Council
are now on file at the office of the City Clerk for public inspection. At least
2 copies, together with all amendments and supplements thereto, shall be kept
available at the City Clerk’s office for public inspection.
   (C)   Applicability. This chapter and the rules and regulations adopted
herein shall govern and regulate plumbing and plumbing installation and
plumbing systems in all buildings and building additions and alterations within
the city, including private residences of 1- and 2-family dwelling units and
out-buildings in connection therewith and including barns and private garages.
   (D)   Amendments. The standards, rules, tests, charts, maps and regulations
as set forth in Volume III of the Plumbing Rules and Regulations of the state’s
Administrative Building Council, as amended and adopted, are hereby amended to
read as follows.
      (1)   The following language is hereby deleted from § 1003 Volume III of
the Plumbing Rules and Regulations, as amended and adopted by the state’s
Administrative Building Council.
   “The requirements of this Section need not apply to wall mounted hose
attachments for laundry purposes, outside sill cocks or frost-proof sill
cocks.”
      (2)   There is hereby added to § 1003 Volume III of the Plumbing Rules
and Regulations, as amended and adopted by the State Administrative Building
Council, the following subsection 1003 (q), as amended by the State
Administrative Building Council.
   “Valve outlets for hose attachments. Valve outlets with hose attachments
shall be protected by an approved vacuum breaker. The vacuum breaker may be
permanently attached to the hose threads of the valve outlet, or may be an
integral part of the valve. The vacuum breaker is not required for wall mounted
hose attachments for laundry purposes.”
(Prior Code, § 156.02) (Ord. 3947, passed 11-26-1973; Am. Ord. 4334, passed 6-
27-1977)
Statutory reference:
   Authority of city to incorporate material by reference, see I.C. 36-1-5-4
PLUMBERS
§ 156.10 LICENSE AND REGISTRATION REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of
plumbing construction improvements within the city without first obtaining a
license from the state’s Plumbing Commissioner in accordance with the
provisions of I.C. 25-28.5-1-1 et seq., and without first registering with the
Building Commissioner of the city in accordance with the provisions of this
subchapter.
   (B)   The registration requirements of this subchapter shall not apply to
any person who is exempted pursuant to I.C. 25-28.5-1-1 et seq., from obtaining
a state license.
(Prior Code, § 156.05) (Ord. 3947, passed 11-26-1973)
Penalty, see § 10.99
Statutory reference:
   Authority of city to regulate and license professions, see I.C. 36-8-2-10
§ 156.11 REGISTRATION PROCEDURE; FEE.
   (A)   All persons desiring to engage in the practice of plumbing within the
city shall submit a registration form to be prescribed by the City Controller,
together with the fee prescribed herein. The registration form shall include
any information that will enable the Inspections Department to determine
whether or not the person is duly licensed by the state under I.C. 25-28.5 and
any other information that will enable the Inspections Department to insure
compliance with all applicable laws, provisions of this code and other
ordinances of the city.
   (B)   The registration fee shall be $200 for each new registration and $100
per year registration renewal if renewed by January 31 of each subsequent year.
The City Controller upon receipt of registration and fee and following
investigation by the Inspections Department, shall issue the applicant a
registration certificate and shall have the Inspections Department place the
applicant’s name upon the list of registered plumbers.
   (C)   All registrations are effective for the calendar year and
registrations will expire on December 31 of each year. No registration shall be
issued for a period greater than 1 year. The full annual fee must be paid,
regardless of when registration occurs and when there will be no proration of
fee, nor refund of fee upon revocation or expiration of registration.
   (D)   Registrations renewed more than 31 days after expiration, shall be
subject to an additional late fee of $100. Registrations which have been
expired for 180 days or longer are no longer valid, and the application will be
treated as a new registration.
   (E)   Any person registering with the city following the issuance of a
residential stop work order for failure to be registered shall pay an
additional $250 in addition to the initial fee at the time of registration.
   (F)   Any person registering with the city following the issuance of a
commercial stop work order for failure to be registered shall pay an additional
$500 in addition to the initial fee at the time of registration.
   (G)   A registration is not transferable. Should a person, during the course
of the registration year, fail to remain licensed by the state under I.C. 25-
28.5, then the city registration will automatically terminate.
(Prior Code, § 156.06) (Ord. 3947, passed 11-26-1973; Am. Ord. 9209, passed 5-
13-2013; Am. Ord. 9446, passed 9-23-2019) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 156.12 BOND.
   (A)   (1)   No plumbing permit shall be issued to any applicant for
registration to do a job of plumbing or plumbing work until the applicant shall
have filed with the City Controller an indemnifying bond to be approved by the
City Controller, payable to the city and all parties affected, in the penal sum
of $5,000 with good and sufficient surety.
      (2)   This bond shall be conditioned on the fact that the permittee will
not violate any of the provisions of this code or other ordinances relative to
plumbing or the Administrative Building Council Plumbing Rules and Regulations,
Administrative Rules and Regulations (20-421) M.
      (3)   The bond shall be further conditioned to reimburse any person from
whom the licensee may do plumbing work whereby the person may be damaged by
virtue of any improper work or neglect of the applicant in violating any of the
terms of this code or other ordinances of the city relative to plumbing or the
Administrative Building Council Plumbing Rules and Regulations, Administrative
Rules and Regulations (20-421) M.
   (B)   The bond shall expire on the same date as the registration and shall
be renewed each year when application for a new registration is made.
(Prior Code, § 156.12) (Ord. 3947, passed 11-26-1973)
INSTALLATION AND CONSTRUCTION
§ 156.20 PERMIT REQUIRED; FEES.
   (A)   Before any plumbing work of any kind shall be commenced for any
building or structure, or on any lot or premises; or before the excavation
shall commence on any street, avenue, road, sidewalk or highway, or any other
public place, excepting repairs under $500, proper permits shall first be
obtained. Any person, contractor, or company desiring a plumbing permit for
work to be performed in the city shall, at the time the permit is issued
therefor, pay to the City Controller, a fee for their portion of the contracted
price of the project, as required in this section. TOTAL VALUATION on any
construction shall be the contract price, and shall include, but not be limited
to, all labor, materials, subcontractors, permanent equipment and/or fixtures
and all costs associated with job supervision. Minimum plumbing permit fee
shall be $50.
   (B)   A plumbing permit shall be obtained for the installation of air-
conditioning units and refrigeration units where city water is used, as well as
city water pipes and waste pipes.
   (C)   No person other than a person having obtained a plumbing license from
the state and registered with the city as provided in § 156.11, shall open or
dig any street, avenue, road, boulevard, sidewalk, alley, parkway or any other
public place for tapping any public sewer, installing or connecting any
building or storm sewer, or installing water service or water main in the city
without first making an application to the Inspection Department for a permit.
The applicant shall file a sketch with the Inspection Department’s Building
Commissioner, showing and specifying the exact location where the work shall be
performed with the number of the lot, the name of the street, alley or other
place, and the name of the person or persons owning the lot or portion thereof
to be served. The Board of Public Works and Safety shall grant approval prior
to the digging into any public right-of-way. The Sewer Department of the city
shall be notified before any tapping or connection shall be done in accordance
with the specifications of the Sewer Department and the Engineering Department.
   (D)   Any person obtaining a permit following the issuance of a residential
stop work order from the Building Commissioner shall pay an additional $250 to
the permit fee listed below.
   (E)   Any person obtaining a permit following the issuance of a commercial
stop work order from the Building Commissioner shall pay an additional $500 to
the permit fee listed below.
   (F)   It shall be unlawful for any person obtaining a permit under this
chapter to assign, transfer or sublet the permit. No contractor shall pull a
permit to be used by another contractor or person.
   (G)   The permit fees for installation and inspection (and reinspection) of
plumbing shall be as follows.

§ 156.21 SUPERVISION; INSPECTION.
   The installation of air-conditioning units and refrigeration units where
city water is used, water pipes and waste pipes shall be installed under the
supervision of a master plumber. Inspection of the work shall be made by the
Chief Plumbing Inspector.
(Prior Code, § 156.16) (Ord. 3947, passed 11-26-1973)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 156.22 PUBLIC SEWERS.
   All construction and laying of a new public sewer shall be done with the
approval of the Board of Public Works and Safety and in accordance with the
plans and specifications of the City Engineer.
(Prior Code, § 156.17) (Ord. 3947, passed 11-26-1973)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 156.23 OPENINGS IN STREETS, SIDEWALKS, AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES.
   (A)   All openings made in streets, alleys, sidewalks or any other public
place shall be protected at all hours by sufficient barriers on which signal
lights or flares shall be placed and maintained after dark. Also it shall be
the duty of the Master Plumber to notify the Police and Fire Department when
any streets, alleys, sidewalks or any other public places are fully obstructed.
   (B)   The amount of deposit required for the repairs for each opening of any
street, alley, sidewalk, parkway or any other public place shall be $100
payable to the City Controller.
(Prior Code, § 156.18) (Ord. 3947, passed 11-26-1973)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 156.24 SUBSOIL DRAINAGE.
   (A)   Discharge by gravity. Subsoil drains shall discharge into a sump not
less than 18 inches in diameter, from which a connection shall be made to the
building drain, building sewer or storm sewer. This connection shall be
properly trapped and a check valve installed to prevent back flow of sewage.
   (B)   Discharge mechanically. Where the contents of a subsoil drain are
discharged by mechanical devices, the contents shall drain into a sand
interceptor or sump, from which it shall be bypassed into the sump pump, and
then lifted and discharged into the building drain, building sewer or storm
sewer.
(Prior Code, § 156.19) (Ord. 3947, passed 11-26-1973)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 156.25 INSTALLATIONS BY OWNERS.
   A bona-fide owner of a residence desiring to install, remodel or repair the
plumbing system within his or her premises shall comply with all the laws,
rules and regulations of this chapter and in this event the word “owner” shall
be substituted for the word “plumber”. The owner shall secure all the necessary
plumbing permits and shall comply with all regulations of the Water Department.
(Prior Code, § 156.20) (Ord. 3947, passed 11-26-1973)
Penalty, see § 10.99
CHIEF PLUMBING INSPECTOR
§ 156.35 APPOINTMENT; TERM.
   The Mayor shall appoint a competent person to be known as Chief Plumbing
Inspector and any assistants as may be necessary to enforce this chapter. The
Chief Plumbing Inspector shall hold office during the pleasure of the Mayor and
until his or her successor is duly appointed and qualified.
(Prior Code, § 156.25) (Ord. 3947, passed 11-26-1973)
§ 156.36 QUALIFICATIONS.
   The Chief Plumbing Inspector shall be a property owner in the city, a
resident of the city for not less than 2 years and be a journeyman plumber with
not less than 5 years of plumbing experience.
(Prior Code, § 156.26) (Ord. 3947, passed 11-26-1973)
§ 156.37 OATH; BOND.
   Before entering his or her duties, the Chief Plumbing Inspector shall be
required to take and subscribe to an oath of office that he or she will
faithfully perform the duties of the office; and he or she shall be required to
file a surety bond in the sum of $5,000 payable to the city, conditioned upon
faithful performance of his or her duties. This bond shall be filed in the
office of the City Controller. The bond may be executed with any recognized and
responsible surety company authorized to do business in the state as a surety
thereon.
(Prior Code, § 156.27) (Ord. 3947, passed 11-26-1973)
Statutory reference:
   This section has been modified by I.C. 5-4-1-18(c)(2) which requires a bond
of at least $30,000
§ 156.38 ENGAGING IN PLUMBING BUSINESS WHILE IN OFFICE.
   It shall be unlawful for the Chief Plumbing Inspector and his or her
assistants to engage in the business of master plumber or journeyman plumber in
the city during his or her term of office as Chief Plumbing Inspector.
(Prior Code, § 156.28) (Ord. 3947, passed 11-26-1973)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 156.39 RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   On complaint, the Chief Plumbing Inspector shall have the right to enter any
business, residential building, industrial plant or factory for the purpose of
investigating the sanitary condition of the building, plant, factory or
residential building at any reasonable hour of the day.
(Prior Code, § 156.29) (Ord. 3947, passed 11-26-1973)
§ 156.40 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   Supervision of plumbing works and office hours. The Chief Plumbing
Inspector shall have immediate supervision of all plumbing works. He or she
shall maintain office hours necessary to efficiently administer the provisions
of this chapter.
   (B)   Permits and examination of work, issuance generally. The Chief
Plumbing Inspector shall require submission of, examine and check plans and
specifications, drawings, descriptions and diagrams necessary to show clearly
the character, kind and extent of plumbing work covered by the application for
a permit and upon approval thereof, issue the permit.
   (C)   Copies. Plumbing permits shall be issued in triplicate, and the
original permit shall be given to the applicant, the second copy with the
amount of fee as shown on the permit shall be given to the City Controller, and
the third copy shall remain in the Building Commissioner’s office.
   (D)   Certificates of approval or rejection. The Chief Plumbing Inspector
shall inspect and issue a certificate of approval or rejection for any work
approved or rejected by him or her.
   (E)   Records of licensed and registered plumbers. The Chief of Plumbing
Inspector shall maintain an official record of all persons lawfully entitled to
carry on or engage in the business of plumbing in the city to whom a state
license has been issued and registered by the City Controller.
   (F)   Powers granted. The Chief Plumbing Inspector is hereby given the
powers set forth in this chapter in addition to those given to him or her by
virtue of any other law.
(Prior Code, § 156.30) (Ord. 3947, passed 11-26-1973)
Penalty, see § 10.99

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 157.001 SHORT TITLE.
   This chapter shall be known and cited as the “City of Hammond Subdivision
Regulations”.
(Prior Code, § 158.01) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.002 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter shall be to provide rules, regulations, and
standards in order to achieve orderly development in the city through land
subdivision; to promote the utilization of land to assure to the residents of
the city the best possible environment; to cause land subdivision and re-
subdivision to be made in accordance with the Land Use Plan and Zoning
Ordinance of the city; and to promote the health, safety and welfare of the
citizens of the city. It shall be administered to ensure the orderly growth and
development, the conservation, protection and proper use of land by adequate
provision for circulation, utilities and services.
(Prior Code, § 158.02) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.003 ADMINISTRATIVE AUTHORITY.
   The City Plan Commission, as established by virtue of I.C. 36-7-4-100 et
seq., as amended, is established as the administrative agency for this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 158.03) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.004 INTERPRETATION.
   In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this chapter
shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the health,
safety, comfort, prosperity or general welfare of the citizens of the city.
(Prior Code, § 158.04) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.005 JURISDICTION AND SUBDIVISION COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   (A)   This chapter shall apply to all subdivisions of land within the
corporate limits of the city as now or hereafter established. Single lot
subdivisions of 5 or more acres are, however, exempt from the provisions of
this chapter.
   (B)   No subdivision, or replat of any lot, tract or parcel of land shall be
affected, nor shall any street, sanitary sewer, storm sewer, water main or
other facility in connection therewith be laid out, constructed, opened or
dedicated for public use or for the common use of occupants of buildings
abutting thereon, except in strict accordance with the provisions of this
chapter.
   (C)   No lot shall be sold, nor shall an improvement location permit or a
building permit to erect, alter or repair any building upon land be issued,
unless and until a subdivision has been approved and recorded, and until the
improvements required by the city in connection therewith have been constructed
or guaranteed as provided in this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 158.05) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.006 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ADMINISTRATOR. The designated administrator is the City Planner because of
his or her training in the principles of subdividing.
   BLOCK. A tract of land bounded by a street or streets and any combination of
boundary lines of public or institutionally owned lands, railroad right-of-way,
rivers, lakes and other lines of demarcation.
   BOARD. The Board of Public Works and Safety of the city.
   BOND. Any form of security including cash, surety bond or financial
instrument of credit, as approved by the Board, for the purpose of guaranteeing
that improvements be made in a subdivision according to the standards as
adopted by the Board.
   BUILDING SET BACK LINE. The area in which no permanent structure shall be
constructed or located.
   CEMETERY. An area set apart for or containing graves or tombs; a graveyard.
   COMMISSION. The City Plan Commission of the city.
   COUNCIL. The Common Council of the city.
   COMPREHENSIVE PLAN. A plan for the physical development of the community,
prepared and adopted by the Commission pursuant to state law, and including any
part of the plan separately adopted and any amendment to such plan, or parts
thereof.
   CROSSWALK. A right-of-way dedicated to public use, which cuts across a block
to facilitate pedestrian access to adjacent streets and properties.
   DEVELOPER. The owner of land proposed to be subdivided, or his or her
representative.
   EASEMENT. A grant by a property owner to the general public, a public
utility, a drainage district or a private party for the use of land for a
specifically stated purpose.
   FLOOD PROTECTION ORDINANCE.
Chapter 153 of the city code as amended which sets forth standards as
recommended by the National Flood Insurance Program.
   FRONTAGE. The length along the street right-of-way line of a single lot,
tract or development area between the lot lines of the property. It is that
side of a lot abutting a street and ordinarily regarded as the front of the
lot.
   GRADE. The slope of a lot, street or other public right-of-way in terms of
percentage.
   IMPROVEMENT. Any alteration to the land or other physical constructions
associated with subdivision and building site development.
   INFRASTRUCTURE. The fixed public works and facilities necessary in a
community, such as sewers, water systems, streets, sidewalks and street lights.
   INTERESTED PARTIES. Property owners within 300 feet of a proposed
subdivision, staff of the Commission and the subdivider.
   LOT.
      (1)   LOT. A parcel or portion of land separated from other parcels or
portions by description, as on a subdivision of record or survey map for
purposes of sale, lease or separate use. Includes the words PARCEL or TRACT.
      (2)   LOT, DOUBLE FRONTAGE. A lot, other than a corner lot, which fronts
on 2 streets.
   MODEL HOME. A dwelling unit used initially for display purposes which
typifies the type of units that will be constructed in the subdivision.
   MONUMENT. Any permanent marker used to identify the boundary lines of any
tract, parcel, lot or street lines.
   OUTLOT. A nonbuildable lot which is to be excluded from the development of
the subdivision because of its potential use as a street extension or other
public purpose.
   OWNER. Any person, firm, association, syndicate, sole proprietorship,
partnership, corporation or any other legal entity having legal title to the
land sought to be subdivided under these regulations.
   PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENT. Residential, commercial, or industrial
development, or combination thereof, of a tract of land under single ownership
or control according to an approved final site development plan.
   PLAT OF SUBDIVISION. The drawing on which the subdivider’s plan of
subdivision is presented to the Commission for approval and which, if approved,
may be submitted to the County Recorder for filing.
   PUBLIC UTILITY. A firm, corporation, municipal department, or board duly
authorized to furnish, or furnishing under regulation to the public,
electricity, gas, steam, communication, central antenna television,
transportation, drainage, sewer or water.
   REGISTERED ENGINEER. An engineer who is licensed in compliance with the laws
of the state.
   REGISTERED LAND SURVEYOR. A surveyor who is licensed in compliance with the
laws of the state.
   REPLAT. The process of allowing for an adjustment of a lot line or lines or
easements, as shown on a recorded subdivision which may or may not affect any
street layout, whether existing or proposed and may or may not increase the
total number of lots within the area proposed to be replatted.
   RE-RECORDING. The process allowing for an adjustment of an easement or
easements, or correction of a drafting or typographical error, as shown on an
approved and recorded subdivision which does not affect the size or
configuration of the lot in question.
   RESERVE STRIP. An area of land between a partial street and adjacent
property, which is reserved or held in public ownership for future street
widening.
   RIGHT-OF-WAY. A strip of land occupied or intended to be occupied by
transportation facilities, public utilities or other special public uses.
RIGHTS-OF-WAY intended for any use involving maintenance by a public agency
shall be dedicated to the public use by the maker of the plat on which the
right-of-way is established.
   STAFF. The staff of the City Plan Commission of the city.
   STANDARDS. A specific and detailed listing of materials and construction
methods for subdivision improvements, standards of construction and design, and
performance bond schedules as adopted by the Board.
   STREETS. A general term denoting a public way for purposes of vehicular
travel, including the entire area within the right-of-way. STREET also includes
the terms highway, parkway, road, thoroughfare, avenue, boulevard, lane, court,
place, drive, trail, terrace and other such terms.
      (1)   ALLEYS. Minor ways which are used as a convenience primarily for
public and utility service at the rear or side of properties otherwise abutting
on a street.
      (2)   COLLECTOR STREETS. Those which are used to carry traffic from local
streets to thoroughfares and highways, including the principal entrance streets
to a residential development and circulation streets within those developments.
      (3)   CUl-DE-SACS. Short streets having one end open to traffic, the
other end being permanently terminated by a vehicle turnaround, not more than
500 feet in length.
      (4)   LOCAL STREETS. Those used primarily for access to the abutting
property.
      (5)   LOOP STREETS. Begin at an intersection with another street, run to
make a loop or “U” of various shapes or properties, and then re-intersect the
street of origin at another point.
      (6)   MARGINAL ACCESS (FRONTAGE) STREETS.  Local streets which are
parallel to and adjacent to thoroughfare streets and highways, and which
provide access to abutting property and protection from through traffic.
      (7)   THOROUGHFARES. Used primarily for fast or heavy traffic.
   SUBDIVIDER. The owner, or duly authorized representative for the owner, of a
piece of property either proposed for subdivision or an existing subdivision.
   SUBDIVISION. Any land, vacant or improved, which is divided into 1 or more
lots for the purpose of sale, lease, or development, using varying types of
financing methods. SUBDIVISION includes the division of replay along with
subsequent development of residentially and commercially zoned land by plat.
These regulations do not apply to:
      (1)   The willing/unwilling sale of land as a result of legal
condemnations as defined and allowed by state statute;
      (2)   Widening of existing streets to conform to the Comprehensive Plan;
and
      (3)   The acquisition of street rights-of-way by a public agency in
conformance with the Comprehensive Plan.
   TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES. All signs, signals, markings, and devices placed or
erected by authority of the Board for the purpose of regulating, warning, or
guiding traffic.
   VARIANCE. A modification of the strict terms of the relevant regulations of
this chapter where the modification will not be contrary to the public interest
and where, owing to conditions peculiar to the property and not the result of
the action of the applicant, a literal enforcement of this chapter would result
in unnecessary and undue hardship. Variances in subdivision regulations are
granted only by the Commission.
   ZONING ORDINANCE. Chapter 159 of the city code.
(Prior Code, § 158.06) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
DESIGN STANDARDS
§ 157.015 COMPREHENSIVE PLAN AND ZONING ORDINANCE.
   The subdivision shall conform to all elements of the Comprehensive Plan, to
all regulations as set forth in the Zoning Ordinance (
Ch. 158) as amended, and to all regulations as set forth in the Flood
Protection Ordinance (
Ch. 153) as amended.
(Prior Code, § 158.15) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.016 STREET REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade, and location of all
streets shall be correlated to existing and planned streets, existing
topography, public safety, and in their appropriate relations to the proposed
uses of the land to be served by those streets.
   (B)   Local streets shall be laid out so that their use by through traffic
will be discouraged.
   (C)   Half-streets may be permitted by the Plan Commission in situations
where their use is unavoidable, but only after discussion between the Developer
and City Planner.
   (D)   No new street shall have a name which duplicates or so nearly
duplicates so as to be confused with any existing street within the city,
unless the new street is to be an extension of an existing street. Continuous
local and collector streets which have major directional changes shall require
a change in street name for each directional change.
(Prior Code, § 158.16) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.017 ALLEYS.
   (A)   New alleys are prohibited in residential areas.
   (B)   Alleys are discouraged, but may be provided, in commercial and
industrial areas if the access to the subdivision for delivery of public and
private services will be impaired without an alley. Alleys will not be less
than 20 feet in width. Dead end alleys, and alleys with sharp directional
changes that impair traffic flow and public/private service vehicles are
prohibited.
(Prior Code, § 158.17) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.018 EASEMENTS.
   Easements centered on rear or side lot lines shall be provided for utilities
where necessary and shall be 7-1/2 feet wide on both sides of the property
line. Easements shall be continuous to the street at the end of the block to
connect with adjoining blocks in the shortest direct route.
(Prior Code, § 158.18) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.019 ELECTRICAL, COMMUNICATION AND CENTRAL ANTENNA TELEVISION UTILITIES.
   (A)   Underground installation is required in residential areas.
   (B)   Underground installation is recommended but not required in commercial
and industrial areas. However, if the commercial and industrial area abuts a
residential area, underground installation shall be required to minimize
negative visual effects, unless aerial installation is 100 feet or more from
the affected residential area.
(Prior Code, § 158.19) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.020 BLOCKS.
   (A)   The width of blocks shall be sufficient to allow 2 tiers of lots,
except where reverse frontage on a major thoroughfare is required.
   (B)   In the event of block length exceeding 1,000 feet, a crosswalk not
less than 10 feet in width may be required near center and entirely across any
block. The crosswalk shall be constructed according to standards as adopted by
the Board and dedicated to the public use.
(Prior Code, § 158.20) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.021 LOTS.
   (A)   Lot sizes shall be platted according to the minimum regulations as set
forth in the Zoning Ordinance as amended.
   (B)   Every lot shall abut and front on a public street.
   (C)   Lots shall be consecutively numbered and addresses shall be assigned
in accordance with the uniform address system of the city.
(Prior Code, § 158.21) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
NEW SUBDIVISION
§ 157.030 CONSULTATION REQUIRED.
   (A)   Prior to the submission of an application for a new subdivision, the
subdivider shall prepare a preliminary plat and consult simultaneously with
both the City Planner and Zoning Administrator.
   (B)   The consultation will foster an understanding between the subdivider
and the staff which will help to alleviate future misunderstandings and reduce
the possibility of extensive revisions.
   (C)   If the preliminary plat meets the provisions of this chapter, the City
Planner shall recommend to the subdivider that an application for a new
subdivision be submitted to the Commission.
(Prior Code, § 158.30) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.031 PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENT ENCOURAGED.
   (A)   The imaginative and creative use of Planned Unit Developments (PUD) is
encouraged.
   (B)   Approval shall be made in conformance with this title.
(Prior Code, § 158.31) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.032 NAME OF SUBDIVISION.
   The name of the subdivision shall not duplicate or closely approximate the
name of any other subdivision within the city so as to avoid confusion.
(Prior Code, § 158.32) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.033 PRELIMINARY PLAT.
   The drawing of the preliminary plat shall be in conformance with the
following requirements:
   (A)   A properly drafted drawing of not less than 1 inch equal to 100 feet;
   (B)   Showing the name of the subdivision;
   (C)   North arrow and scale;
   (D)   Boundary line of proposed subdivision, all existing easements and
property lines in exact dimensions;
   (E)   Location, width, and names of prior subdivided streets and lots and
showing all previously recorded streets and lots in dotted lines;
   (F)   Layout and dimensions of the proposed lots and streets;
   (G)   Parcels to be dedicated for the public use;
   (H)   Existing topographic contours at vertical intervals of 2 feet or less,
proposed contours with vertical elevations;
   (I)   The layout of streets, curbs and sidewalks in the area 300 feet
distant from and parallel to the boundary of the proposed subdivision;
   (J)   A conceptual subdivision plan for adjacent property owned by the
subdivider but not included as part of the proposed subdivision application at
hand; and
   (K)   Preliminary plans for street, curb, sidewalk, sewer and water
installation.
(Prior Code, § 158.33) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.034 THE FINAL PLAT.
   (A)   (1)   The final plat shall be an original ink drawing on not less than
8-1/2 inch by 14 inch vellum, linen or Mylar film at a scale of not less than 1
inch equal to 100 feet, with 5 prints of the drawing.
      (2)   A 1-inch border shall be incorporated into the drawing.
   (B)   The drawing shall show:
      (1)   Name of the subdivision;
      (2)   Location of the subdivision by section, range, township and
boundary legal description;
      (3)   Name and address of subdivider;
      (4)   Name, address, seal and signature of the surveyor preparing the
subdivision;
      (5)   Scale, graphic bar scale, north arrow and date;
      (6)   Boundary line of proposed subdivision, all existing easements and
property lines in exact dimensions of feet and hundredths thereof, all boundary
lines shall have length and bearing designated on the plat;
      (7)   Location, width and names of prior subdivided street and lots in
the proposed subdivision, showing all previously recorded streets and lots in
dotted lines on the preliminary submittal;
      (8)   Layout and dimensions of proposed lots to the nearest one hundredth
foot;
      (9)   Layout and elevations of proposed streets, (street elevations shall
not be less than 596 feet above mean sea level) which includes the
classification of each street, its name and width, walkways, crosswalks and
easements;
      (10)   Parcels of land to be dedicated for public use shall be shown and
labeled as to use;
      (11)   Dimensioned building setback lines;
      (12)   Existing topographic contours at vertical intervals of 2 feet or
less; (Vertical control data shall be based on Coastal and Geodetic Survey Sea
Level Datum.)
      (13)   Elevations for each corner and the center of each lot, with a
minimum of a 2% slope away from the center of the building site in order to
facilitate drainage away from the building;
      (14)   An area 4 inches vertical by 9 inches horizontal, within which the
Commission may affix its certificate of approval; and
      (15)   The City Engineer shall assist the subdivider in determining the
building numbering system in conformance with §
150.095.
(Prior Code, § 158.34) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.035 SITE ANALYSIS BY STAFF.
   The following shall be used as a basis for staff site analysis
recommendation:
   (A)   The drawing requirements as set forth in §
157.034(B)(8);
   (B)   Natural features such as wooded areas, swamps, wetlands, streams and
natural drainage courses;
   (C)   Existing public utilities and capacities;
   (D)   The Comprehensive Plan;
   (E)   The Flood Protection Ordinance;
   (F)   The Zoning Ordinance;
   (G)   The property list showing names and addresses of property owners
within 300 feet of the edges of the proposed subdivision as provided by the
subdivider;
   (H)   The legal notice as printed in a local newspaper of general
circulation a minimum of ten days prior to the public hearing;
   (I)   A completed application form, letter to the Commission stating that he
is the owner or agent for the owner of the land, or a copy of a purchase
agreement; and
   (J)   The appropriate application fees as prescribed by the Commission.
(Prior Code, § 158.35) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.036 PRELIMINARY REVIEW AND FINAL APPROVAL/PROCESS.
   (A)   Within 1 working day after filing the plat of the subdivision with the
staff, the staff shall refer the prints to the Board of Public Works and
Safety, the Board of Directors of the Department of Water Works, the Sanitary
District and the Board of Park and Recreation Commissioners if the subdivision
is within 300 feet of any dedicated park, or with the Department of Natural
Resources if the subdivision lies within a designated flood hazard area as
defined in the Flood Protection Ordinance.
   (B)   The staff of each agency shall review the proposed plat of the
subdivision and submit a report to the Commission staff.
   (C)   The staff shall incorporate these reports into the site analysis
report and make recommendation to the Commission.
   (D)   If the subdivision complies with the regulations of the subdivision
chapter, the staff shall place the subdivision on the agenda of the first
available meeting of the Commission.
   (E)   The staff shall then notify the subdivider of the time, date, and
place of the Commission hearing in writing.
   (F)   The subdivider shall notify all property owners within 300 feet of the
edge of the subdivision of the time, date and place of the Commission hearing.
Notification shall be by certified mail or in person with a signed statement of
receipt by the property owner of the notice of the public hearing. This shall
be done at the expense of the subdivider. All receipts shall be delivered to
the staff at least 2 working days prior to the hearing.
   (G)   The subdivider shall, at his or her own expense, and on a form as
prescribed by the Commission, place a legal notice at least 10 days prior to
the hearing in a local newspaper of general circulation stating the time, place
and date of the hearing and a common description of the location of the
subdivision in conformance with I.C. 5-3-1 et seq. A certified copy of the
legal notice shall be delivered to the staff at least 2 working days prior to
the hearing.
   (H)   If, after a public hearing, the Commission finds that the subdivision
complies with all regulations as set forth in this chapter, the Commission
shall approve the subdivision with or without modifications or conditions
imposed and make written findings of fact which shall include the modifications
and conditions imposed. The Commission President shall sign the plat and that
signature shall be attested to by the Vice President. The staff shall then
provide the subdivider with a copy of the original drawing with the
Commission’s seal affixed thereto. The original plat drawing shall be retained
in the records of the Commission. If, after a public hearing, the Commission
finds that the subdivision does not comply with all standards regarding
approval of subdivisions, the Commission shall deny approval of the subdivision
and write its findings of fact and its decision, which set forth its reasons
for disapproval. The staff shall then release the original drawing to the
subdivider.
(Prior Code, § 158.36) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.037 RECORDING.
   Within 1 year of Plan Commission approval, the subdivider shall record the
subdivision in the Recorder’s Office and so notify the staff. The subdivider
shall also distribute copies of the subdivision plat to the Lake County
Assessor, County Surveyor and the public utility companies.
(Prior Code, § 158.37) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.038 FINAL PLANS.
   Final plans for streets, sewers and water shall be submitted to the Board
after Commission approval but prior 36to recording.
(Prior Code, § 158.38) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)

subdivider shall prepare a preliminary plat and consult simultaneously with
both the City Planner and Zoning Administrator. The consultation will foster an
understanding between the subdivider and the staff which will help to alleviate
future misunderstandings and reduce the possibility of extensive revisions. If
the preliminary plat meets the provisions of the ordinance, the City Planner
shall recommend to the subdivider that an application for subdivision replat be
submitted to the Commission.

SUBDIVISION RE-RECORDINGS
§ 157.070 RE-RECORDING APPLICATION.
   Subdivision re-recording may be submitted at the convenience of the
subdivider. The name of the subdivision shall not be altered. The submission
shall include the following:
   (A)   The original drawing and five copies of the recorded subdivision with
a revision date drafted onto the original plat;
   (B)   A written comment in detailed form of the technical changes performed;
   (C)   The seal and certification of the surveyor preparing the drawing
changes;
   (D)   Proof of ownership or a copy of a purchase agreement; and
   (E)   The applicable fee as prescribed by the Commission.
(Prior Code, § 158.60) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.071 RE-RECORDING REVIEW AND FINAL APPROVAL PROCESS.
   (A)   After filing, the staff may, if necessary, refer the prints of the
subdivision to the appropriate agencies as listed in §
157.035(A). The agencies shall review the subdivision and submit a report to
the staff. The staff shall review the subdivision for technical conformity with
the standards as set forth in this chapter and make recommendation to the
Commission.
   (B)   Upon receipt of the reports from those agencies, the staff shall
review the subdivision and make recommendation to the Commission and place the
subdivision on the agenda of the first available meeting of the Commission and
notify the subdivider of the time, date and place of the meeting in writing.
   (C)   Advertised public notice of the meeting is not required.
   (D)   Commission action.
      (1)   If the Commission finds that the subdivision complies with all
regulations as set forth in the chapter, the Commission shall give approval to
the subdivision with or without modifications imposed, and make written
findings of fact which shall include the modifications and conditions imposed.
The Commission President shall sign the plat and the Vice President shall
attest to his or her signature. The staff shall then provide the subdivider
with a copy of the original drawing with the Commission’s seal affixed thereto.
The original plat shall be retained in the records of the Commission.
      (2)   If the Commission finds that the subdivision does not comply with
all standards regarding approval of subdivisions, the Commission shall deny
approval and make written findings of fact and a decision which sets forth its
reasons for disapproval. The staff shall then release the original drawing to
the subdivider.
(Prior Code, § 158.61) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.072 RECORDING.
   Within 7 days of approval, the subdivider shall record the subdivision in
the recorder’s office and so notify the staff. The subdivider shall also
distribute copies to the Lake County Assessor, County Surveyor and the public
utility companies.
(Prior Code, § 158.62) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
IMPROVEMENTS
§ 157.080 STANDARDS FOR CONSTRUCTION AND INSPECTION.
   All required improvements shall be designed and constructed in accordance
with the latest standards as adopted by the Board. Inspection of the
construction of all required improvements shall be approved by the City
Engineer, and then accepted by the Board, Sanitary District and the Board of
Directors of the Department of Water Works.
(Prior Code, § 158.70) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.081 REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS.
   (A)   All lot corners shall be marked by a monument constructed of wrought
iron pipe or bar at least 18 inches in length and one inch in diameter. The top
of the monument is to be set level with the established grade of the ground.
   (B)   Proper and adequate provision shall be made by the subdivider for
drainage to provide for the disposal of storm water. The developer shall sod
all drainage swales that exceed a 2% gradient. The City Engineer shall assist
the subdivider in order to determine the location, capacity and extent of
drainage swales.
   (C)   The subdivision shall be provided with a complete public sewer and
water system. The work shall be done in conformance with plans, profiles and
specifications prepared by an engineer meeting the standards as adopted by the
Board, the Water Board and the Sanitary District.
   (D)   Sidewalks shall be constructed on both sides of the street in
conformance with standards as adopted by the Board.
   (E)   A complete street lighting system with underground wiring shall be
provided in accordance with standards as adopted by the Board. In order to
decrease the hazards of vehicular and pedestrian traffic accidents, ornamental
street lights shall be installed by the subdivider at all intersections and
other areas as deemed necessary, in a manner as prescribed by the Board of
Public Works and Safety.
   (F)   Trees of a variety approved by the Board of Park and Recreation
Commissioners shall be planted and shall be spaced no closer than 40 feet
apart. The trees will be no less than 2 inches in caliper diameter and must be
located so as not to interfere with public lighting, once mature.
   (G)   Streets and alleys shall be completed according to specifications and
profiles designed by an engineer and meeting the latest standards as approved
by the Board.
   (H)   Curbs and gutters shall be completed according to specifications and
profiles designed by an engineer and meeting the latest standards as approved
by the Board.
(Prior Code, § 158.71) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
ADMINISTRATION
§ 157.090 AMENDMENTS.
   The Commission may from time to time recommend changes in this chapter to
the Common Council, in accordance with state statutes.
(Prior Code, § 158.75) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.091 VARIANCES.
   (A)   Where the Commission finds that extraordinary hardships or practical
difficulties may result from strict compliance with these regulations, the
Commission may approve variances to these subdivision regulations so that
substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured, provided that
the variances shall not have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of
these regulations, and further provided the Commission shall not approve
variances unless it makes findings based upon the evidence presented to it in
each specific case as follows:
      (1)   Granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public
health, safety or welfare or injurious to other property.
      (2)   The conditions upon which the request for a variance is based are
unique to the property for which the variance is sought and are not applicable
generally to other property.
      (3)   Because of the particular surroundings, shape or topographical
conditions of the specific property involved, a particular hardship to the
owner would result, as distinguished from a mere inconvenience if the strict
letter of these regulations are carried out. Financial hardship does not
constitute grounds for a variance.
      (4)   The variance shall not in any manner vary the provisions of the
Zoning Ordinance or Flood Control Ordinance.
   (B)   A petition for any variance shall be submitted in writing by the
subdivider at the time when the sketch plat is filed for the consideration of
the staff. The petition shall state fully the grounds for the application and
all of the facts relied upon by the petitioner.
   (C)   It is not within the jurisdiction of the Board of Zoning Appeals to
grant variances to these regulations.
(Prior Code, § 158.76) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
§ 157.092 APPEALS.
   (A)   Every decision of the Commission shall be subject to review by writ of
certiorari.
   (B)   Any person aggrieved by a decision of the Commission may present to
the circuit or superior court of Lake County, Indiana, a petition, duly
verified, setting forth that the decision is illegal in whole or in part, and
specifying the grounds of the illegality. The petition shall be presented to
the court within 30 days after the entry of the Commission’s decision that is
being challenged.
(Prior Code, § 158.092) (Ord. 4829, passed 6-27-1983)
